Text

There was a glow in the sky as if great furnace doors were opened . But all the afternoon [his]265-his eyes had looked on glamour ; [he]265-his had strayed in [fairyland]266-fairyland . The holidays were nearly done , and [Lucian Taylor]73-lucian had gone out resolved to lose [himself]73-lucian , to discover [strange hills]267-strange hills and prospects that [he]73-lucian had never seen before . The air was still , breathless , exhausted after heavy rain , and the clouds looked as if they had been molded of lead . No breeze blew upon [the hill]268-the hill , and down in [the well of [the valley]270-the valley]269-the well of the valley not a dry leaf stirred , not a bough shook in all [the dark January woods]271-the dark january woods . About a mile from [the rectory]272-the rectory [he]73-lucian had diverged from [the main road]273-the main road by [an opening that promised mystery and adventure]274-an opening that promised mystery and adventure . [It]275-it was [an old neglected lane]276-an old neglected lane , little more than a ditch , worn ten feet deep by [its]275-it winter waters , and shadowed by great untrimmed hedges , densely woven together . On each side were [turbid streams]277-turbid streams , and here and there a torrent of water gushed down the banks , flooding [the lane]278-the lane . It was so deep and dark that [he]73-lucian could not get a glimpse of [the country through which [he]73-lucian was passing]279-the country through which he was passing , but the way went down and down to [some unconjectured hollow]280-some unconjectured hollow . Perhaps [he]73-lucian walked two miles between the high walls of [the lane]278-the lane before its descent ceased , but [he]73-lucian thrilled with the sense of having journeyed very far , all the long way from [the know]282-the know to [the unknown]283-the unknown . [He]73-lucian had come as it were into the bottom of [a bowl amongst the hills]284-a bowl amongst the hills , and [black woods]285-black woods shut out [the world]286-the world . From [the road]287-the road behind [him]73-lucian , from [the road before [him]73-lucian]288-the road before him , from the unseen wells beneath the trees , rivulets of waters swelled and streamed down towards the center to [the brook that crossed [the lane]278-the lane]289-the brook that crossed the lane . Amid the dead and wearied silence of the air , beneath leaden and motionless clouds , it was strange to hear such a tumult of gurgling and rushing water , and [he]73-lucian stood for a while on the quivering footbridge and watched the rush of dead wood and torn branches and wisps of straw , all hurrying madly past [him]73-lucian , to plunge into the heaped spume , the barmy froth that had gathered against a fallen tree . Then [he]73-lucian climbed again , and went up between limestone rocks , higher and higher , till the noise of waters became indistinct , a faint humming of swarming hives in summer . [He]73-lucian walked some distance on [level ground]291-level ground , till there was a break in the banks and a stile on which [he]73-lucian could lean and look out . [He]73-lucian found [himself]73-lucian , as [he]73-lucian had hoped , afar and forlorn ; [he]73-lucian had strayed into outland and [occult territory]292-occult territory . From the eminence of [the lane]278-the lane , skirting the brow of [a hill]294-a hill , [he]73-lucian looked down into [deep valleys]295-deep valleys and dingles , and beyond , across the trees , to [remoter country]296-remoter country , [wild bare hills]297-wild bare hills and [dark wooded lands]298-dark wooded lands meeting the grey still sky . Immediately beneath [his]73-lucian feet the ground sloped steep down to [the valley]270-the valley , [a hillside of close grass patched with dead bracken]300-a hillside of close grass patched with dead bracken , and dotted here and there with stunted thorns , and below there were [deep oak woods]301-deep oak woods , all still and silent , and lonely as if [no one]302-no one ever passed that way . The grass and bracken and thorns and woods , all were brown and grey beneath the leaden sky , and as [Lucian]73-lucian looked [he]73-lucian was amazed , as though [he]73-lucian were reading a wonderful story , the meaning of which was a little greater than [his]73-lucian understanding . Then , like [the hero of a fairy - book]303-the hero of a fairy - book , [he]73-lucian went on and on , catching now and again glimpses of [the amazing country into which [he]73-lucian had penetrated]304-the amazing country into which he had penetrated , and perceiving rather than seeing that as the day waned everything grew more grey and somber . As [he]73-lucian advanced [he]73-lucian heard the evening sounds of [the farms]305-the farms , the low of the cattle , and the barking of the sheepdogs ; a faint thin noise from far away . It was growing late , and as the shadows blackened [he]73-lucian walked faster , till once more [the lane]278-the lane began to descend , there was a sharp turn , and [he]73-lucian found [himself]73-lucian , with a good deal of relief , and a little disappointment , on familiar ground . [He]73-lucian had nearly described a circle , and knew this end of [the lane]278-the lane very well ; it was not much more than a mile from [home]308-home . [He]73-lucian walked smartly down [the hill]268-the hill ; the air was all glimmering and indistinct , transmuting trees and hedges into ghostly shapes , and the walls of [the White House Farm]310-the white house farm flickered on [the hillside]311-the hillside , as if they were moving towards [him]73-lucian . Then a change came . First , a little breath of wind brushed with a dry whispering sound through the hedges , the few leaves left on the boughs began to stir , and one or two danced madly , and as the wind freshened and came up from a new quarter , the sapless branches above rattled against one another like bones . The growing breeze seemed to clear the air and lighten it . [He]73-lucian was passing the stile where a path led to [[old Mrs. Gibbon]74-old mrs. gibbon 's desolate little cottage]312-old mrs. gibbon 's desolate little cottage , in [the middle of [the fields]314-the fields]313-the middle of the fields , at some distance even from [the lane]278-the lane , and [he]73-lucian saw the light blue smoke of [her]316-her chimney rise distinct above the gaunt greengage trees , against a pale band that was broadening along the horizon . As [he]73-lucian passed [the stile]317-the stile with [his]73-lucian head bent , and [his]73-lucian eyes on the ground , something white started out from the black shadow of the hedge , and in the strange twilight , now tinged with a flush from the west , a figure seemed to swim past [him]73-lucian and disappear . For a moment [he]73-lucian wondered who it could be , the light was so flickering and unsteady , so unlike the real atmosphere of the day , when [he]73-lucian recollected it was only [Annie Morgan]75-annie , [[old Morgan]75-annie 's daughter at [the White House]319-the white house]318-old morgan 's daughter at the white house . [She]75-annie was three years older than [he]73-lucian , and it annoyed [him]73-lucian to find that though [she]75-annie was only fifteen , there had been a dreadful increase in [her]75-annie height since the summer holidays . [He]73-lucian had got to [the bottom of [the hill]268-the hill]320-the bottom of the hill , and , lifting up [his]73-lucian eyes , saw the strange changes of the sky . The pale band had broadened into a clear vast space of light , and above , the heavy leaden clouds were breaking apart and driving across the heaven before the wind . [He]73-lucian stopped to watch , and looked up at [the great mound that jutted out from [the hills into mid - valley]323-the hills into mid - valley]322-the great mound that jutted out from the hills into mid - valley . [It]322-the great mound that jutted out from the hills into mid - valley was a natural formation , and always [it]322-the great mound that jutted out from the hills into mid - valley must have had something of the form of [a fort]324-a fort , but [its]322-the great mound that jutted out from the hills into mid - valley steepness had been increased by Roman art , and there were high banks on the summit which [[Lucian]73-lucian 's father]325-lucian 's father had told [him]73-lucian were [the vallum of [the camp]327-the camp]326-the vallum of the camp , and [a deep ditch]328-a deep ditch had been dug to the north to sever it from [the hillside]311-the hillside . On this summit oaks had grown , queer stunted - looking trees with twisted and contorted trunks , and writhing branches ; and these now stood out black against the lighted sky . And then the air changed once more ; the flush increased , and a spot like blood appeared in [the pond]330-the pond by the gate , and all the clouds were touched with fiery spots and dapples of flame ; here and there it looked as if awful furnace doors were being opened . The wind blew wildly , and it came up through [the woods]331-the woods with a noise like a scream , and a great oak by [the roadside]332-the roadside ground [its]322-the great mound that jutted out from the hills into mid - valley boughs together with a dismal grating jar . As the red gained in the sky , [the earth]333-the earth and all upon it glowed , even [the grey winter fields]334-the grey winter fields and [the bare hillsides]335-the bare hillsides crimsoned , [the waterpools]336-the waterpools were cisterns of molten brass , and [the very road]337-the very road glittered . [He]73-lucian was wonder - struck , almost aghast , before the scarlet magic of the afterglow . [The old Roman fort]338-the old roman fort was invested with fire ; flames from heaven were smitten about [its]338-the old roman fort walls , and above there was a dark floating cloud , like fume of smoke , and every haggard writhing tree showed as black as midnight against the black of the furnace . When [he]73-lucian got [home]308-home [he]73-lucian heard [[his]73-lucian mother]340-his mother 's voice calling : " Here 's [Lucian]73-lucian at last . [Mary]76-mary , [Master Lucian]73-lucian has come , [you]73-lucian can get the tea ready . "[340-his mother] [He]73-lucian told a long tale of [his]73-lucian adventures , and felt somewhat mortified when [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father seemed perfectly acquainted with the whole course of [the lane]278-the lane , and knew the names of [the wild woods through which [he]341-his father had passed]343-the wild woods through which he had passed in awe . " [You]73-lucian must have gone by [the Darren]1-the darren , [I]341-his father suppose"â€”that[341-his father] was all [he]341-his father said . " Yes , [I]341-his father noticed the sunset ; [we]1623-we shall have some stormy weather . [I]341-his father do n't expect to see many in [church]1624-church tomorrow . "[341-his father] There was buttered toast for tea " because it was holidays . "[341-his father] The red curtains were drawn , and a bright fire was burning , and there was the old familiar furniture , a little shabby , but charming from association . It was much pleasanter than [the cold and squalid schoolroom]344-the cold and squalid schoolroom ; and much better to be reading [Chambers]77-chambers 's Journal than learning [Euclid]78-euclid ; and better to talk to [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father and [mother]346-mother than to be answering such remarks as : " [I]346-mother say , [Taylor]79-mr. taylor , [I]346-mother 've torn [my]346-mother trousers ; how much do [you]79-mr. taylor charge for mending ? "[346-mother] " [Lucy]80-lucy , [dear]1625-dear , come quick and sew this button on [my]73-lucian shirt . "[73-lucian] That night the storm woke [him]73-lucian , and [he]73-lucian groped with [his]73-lucian hands amongst the bedclothes , and sat up , shuddering , not knowing where [he]73-lucian was . [He]73-lucian had seen [himself]73-lucian , in a dream , within [the Roman fort]347-the roman fort , working some dark horror , and the furnace doors were opened and a blast of flame from heaven was smitten upon [him]73-lucian . [Lucian]73-lucian went slowly , but not discreditably , up [the school]348-the school , gaining prizes now and again , and falling in love more and more with useless reading and unlikely knowledge . [He]73-lucian did [his]73-lucian elegiacs and iambics well enough , but [he]73-lucian preferred exercising [himself]73-lucian in the rhymed Latin of the middle ages . [He]73-lucian liked history , but [he]73-lucian loved to meditate on [a land laid waste]349-a land laid waste , [[Britain]2-britain deserted by [the legions]351-the legions]350-britain deserted by the legions , the rare pavements riven by frost , Celtic magic still brooding on [the wild hills]352-the wild hills and in [the black depths of the forest]353-the black depths of the forest , the rosy marbles stained with rain , and the walls growing grey . [The masters]354-the masters did not encourage these researches ; a pure enthusiasm , [they]354-the masters felt , should be for cricket and football , [the dilettanti]355-the dilettanti might even play fives and read Shakespeare without blame , but [healthy English boys]356-healthy english boys should have nothing to do with decadent periods . [He]73-lucian was once found guilty of recommending [Villon]81-villon to [a school - fellow named [Barnes]82-barnes]357-a school - fellow named barnes . [Barnes]82-barnes tried to extract unpleasantness from the text during preparation , and rioted in [his]82-barnes place , owing to [his]82-barnes incapacity for the language . The matter was a serious one ; [the headmaster]358-the headmaster had never heard of [Villon]81-villon , and [the culprit]359-the culprit gave up the name of [[his]359-the culprit literary admirer]360-his literary admirer without remorse . Hence , sorrow for [Lucian]73-lucian , and complete immunity for [the miserable illiterate Barnes]361-the miserable illiterate barnes , who resolved to confine [his]361-the miserable illiterate barnes researches to the Old Testament , a book which [the headmaster]358-the headmaster knew well . As for [Lucian]73-lucian , [he]73-lucian plodded on , learning [his]73-lucian work decently , and sometimes doing very creditable Latin and Greek prose . [[His]361-the miserable illiterate barnes school - fellows]363-his school - fellows thought [him]361-the miserable illiterate barnes quite mad , and tolerated [him]361-the miserable illiterate barnes , and indeed were very kind to [him]361-the miserable illiterate barnes in [their]363-his school - fellows barbarous manner . [He]73-lucian often remembered in after life acts of generosity and good nature done by [wretches like [Barnes]82-barnes , who had no care for [old French nor for curious meters]365-old french nor for curious meters]364-wretches like barnes , who had no care for old french nor for curious meters , and such recollections always moved [him]73-lucian to emotion . [Travelers]366-travelers tell such tales ; cast upon cruel shores amongst [savage races]367-savage races , [they]366-travelers have found no little kindness and warmth of hospitality . [He]73-lucian looked forward to the holidays as joyfully as the rest of [them]368-them . [Barnes]82-barnes and [[his]82-barnes friend]369-his friend [Duscot]83-duscot used to tell [him]73-lucian [their]363-his school - fellows plans and anticipation ; [they]363-his school - fellows were going [home]308-home to [brothers]371-brothers and [sisters]372-sisters , and to cricket , more cricket , or to football , more football , and in the winter there were parties and jollities of all sorts . In return [he]73-lucian would announce [his]73-lucian intention of studying the Hebrew language , or perhaps [Provençal]84-provençal , with a walk up [a bare and desolate mountain]373-a bare and desolate mountain by way of open - air amusement , and on a rainy day for choice . [Whereupon Barnes]82-barnes would impart to [Duscot]83-duscot [his]73-lucian confident belief that [old Taylor]79-mr. taylor was quite cracked . It was a queer , funny life that of [school]374-school , and so very unlike anything in [Tom Brown]85-tom brown . [He]73-lucian once saw [the headmaster]358-the headmaster patting the head of [[the bishop]376-the bishop 's little boy]377-the bishop 's little boy , while [he]358-the headmaster called [him]377-the bishop 's little boy " [[my]358-the headmaster little man]1626-my little man , "[358-the headmaster] and smiled hideously . [He]73-lucian told the tale grotesquely in [the lower fifth room]378-the lower fifth room the same day , and earned much applause , but forfeited all liking directly by proposing a voluntary course of scholastic logic . [One barbarian]379-one barbarian threw [him]73-lucian to the ground and another jumped on [him]73-lucian , but it was done very pleasantly . There were , indeed , [some few of a worse class in [the school]348-the school]380-some few of a worse class in the school , [solemn sycophants]382-solemn sycophants , [prigs perfected from tender years , who thought life already " serious , "[383-prigs perfected from tender years , who thought life already " serious , " and yet , as the headmaster] and yet , as the headmaster]383-prigs perfected from tender years , who thought life already " serious , " and yet , as the headmaster said , were " [joyous , manly young fellows]1627-joyous , manly young fellows . "[380-some few of a worse class in the school] [Some of [these]380-some few of a worse class in the school]384-some of these dressed for dinner at [home]308-home , and talked of dances when [they]384-some of these came back in January . But this virulent sort was comparatively infrequent , and achieved great success in after life . Taking [his]73-lucian school days as a whole , [he]73-lucian always spoke up for the system , and years afterward [he]73-lucian described with enthusiasm the strong beer at [a roadside tavern]386-a roadside tavern , some way out of [the town]387-the town . But [he]73-lucian always maintained that the taste for tobacco , acquired in early life , was the great life , was the great note of [the English Public School]388-the english public school . Three years after [Lucian]73-lucian 's discovery of [the narrow lane]389-the narrow lane and the vision of [the flaming fort]390-the flaming fort , the August holidays brought [him]73-lucian [home]308-home at a time of great heat . It was one of those memorable years of English weather , when some Provençal spell seems wreathed round [the island]392-the island in [the northern sea]393-the northern sea , and the grasshoppers chirp loudly as the cicadas , the hills smell of rosemary , and white walls of [the old farmhouses]394-the old farmhouses blaze in the sunlight as if [they]384-some of these stood in [Arles]3-arles or [Avignon]4-avignon or famed [Tarascon]5-tarascon by [Rhone]6-rhone . [[Lucian]73-lucian 's father]325-lucian 's father was late at [the station]396-the station , and consequently [Lucian]73-lucian bought the Confessions of an English Opium Eater which [he]73-lucian saw on the bookstall . When [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father did drive up , [Lucian]73-lucian noticed that [the old trap]398-the old trap had had a new coat of dark paint , and that the pony looked advanced in years . " [I]341-his father was afraid that [I]341-his father should be late , [Lucian]73-lucian , "[341-his father] said [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father , " though [I]341-his father made [old Polly]76-mary go like anything . [I]341-his father was just going to tell [George]86-george to put [her]76-mary into the trap when [young Philip Harris]87-young philip harris came to [me]341-his father in a terrible state . [He]87-young philip harris said [[his]87-young philip harris father]341-his father fell down ' all of a sudden like ' in the middle of [the field]1629-the field , and [they]1630-they could n't make [him]87-young philip harris speak , and would [I]341-his father please to come and see [him]87-young philip harris . So [I]341-his father had to go , though [I]341-his father could n't do anything for [the poor fellow]1631-the poor fellow . [They]1630-they had sent for [Dr. Burrows]88-dr. burrows , and [I]341-his father am afraid [he]88-dr. burrows will find it a bad case of sunstroke . [The old people]1632-the old people say [they]1632-the old people never remember such a heat before . "[341-his father] The pony jogged steadily along [the burning turnpike road]400-the burning turnpike road , taking revenge for the hurrying on the way to [the station]396-the station . [The hedges]402-the hedges were white with the limestone dust , and the vapor of heat palpitated over [the fields]314-the fields . [Lucian]73-lucian showed [his]73-lucian Confessions to [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father , and began to talk of the beautiful bits [he]73-lucian had already found . [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor knew the book wellâ€”had read it many years before . Indeed [he]79-mr. taylor was almost as difficult to surprise as that character in [Daudet]89-daudet , who had one formula for all the chances of life , and when [he]79-mr. taylor saw [the drowned Academician]1633-the drowned academician dragged out of [the river]1634-the river , merely observed "[79-mr. taylor] J'ai vu tout ça . " [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor [the parson]1635-the parson , as [[his]79-mr. taylor parishioners]1636-his parishioners called [him]79-mr. taylor , had read the fine books and loved [the hills and woods]1637-the hills and woods , and now knew no more of pleasant or sensational surprises . Indeed the living was much depreciated in value , and [his]79-mr. taylor own private means were reduced almost to vanishing point , and under such circumstances the great style loses many of its finer savors . [He]79-mr. taylor was very fond of [Lucian]73-lucian , and cheered by [his]73-lucian return , but in the evening [he]73-lucian would be [a sad man]1638-a sad man again , with [his]73-lucian head resting on one hand , and eyes reproaching sorry fortune . [Nobody]1639-nobody called out "[79-mr. taylor] Here 's [[your]405-your master]406-your master with [Master Lucian]73-lucian ; [you]405-your can get tea ready , " when [the pony]1640-the pony jogged up to the front door . [[His]73-lucian mother]340-his mother had been dead a year , and [a cousin]1642-a cousin kept [house]1643-house . [She]1642-a cousin was [a respectable person called [Deacon]90-miss deacon]1644-a respectable person called deacon , of middle age , and ordinary standards ; and , consequently , there was cold mutton on the table . There was a cake , but nothing of flour , baked in ovens , would rise at [Miss Deacon]90-miss deacon 's evocation . Still , the meal was laid in [the beloved "[79-mr. taylor] parlor]1645-the beloved " parlor , " with the view of [hills and valleys]1646-hills and valleys and [climbing woods]1647-climbing woods from the open window , and the old furniture was still pleasant to see , and the old books in the shelves had many memories . One of the most respected of the armchairs had become weak in the castors and had to be artfully propped up , but [Lucian]73-lucian found it very comfortable after the hard forms . When tea was over [he]73-lucian went out and strolled in [the garden]1648-the garden and [orchards]1649-orchards , and looked over the stile down into [the brake]1650-the brake , where foxgloves and bracken and broom mingled with the hazel undergrowth , where [he]73-lucian knew of secret glades and untracked recesses , deep in the woven green , the cabinets for many years of [his]73-lucian lonely meditations . Every path about [[his]73-lucian home]1651-his home , [every field]1652-every field and hedgerow had dear and friendly memories for [him]73-lucian ; and the odor of the meadowsweet was better than the incense steaming in the sunshine . [He]73-lucian loitered , and hung over the stile till [the far - off woods]1653-the far - off woods began to turn purple , till the white mists were wreathing in [the valley]270-the valley . Day after day , through all that August , morning and evening were wrapped in haze ; day after day [the earth]333-the earth shimmered in the heat , and the air was strange , unfamiliar . As [he]73-lucian wandered in [the lanes]1656-the lanes and sauntered by the cool sweet verge of [the woods]331-the woods , [he]73-lucian saw and felt that nothing was common or accustomed , for the sunlight transfigured [the meadows]1658-the meadows and changed all the form of [the earth]333-the earth . Under the violent Provençal sun , the elms and beeches looked exotic trees , and in the early morning , when the mists were thick , [the hills]1660-the hills had put on an unearthly shape . The one adventure of the holidays was the visit to [the Roman fort]347-the roman fort , to [that fantastic hill about whose steep bastions and haggard oaks [he]73-lucian had seen the flames of sunset writhing nearly three years before]1662-that fantastic hill about whose steep bastions and haggard oaks he had seen the flames of sunset writhing nearly three years before . Ever since that Saturday evening in January , [the lonely valley]1663-the lonely valley had been [a desirable place to [him]73-lucian]1664-a desirable place to him ; [he]73-lucian had watched the green battlements in summer and winter weather , had seen the heaped mounds rising dimly amidst the drifting rain , had marked the violent height swim up from the ice - white mists of summer evenings , had watched the fairy bulwarks glimmer and vanish in hovering April twilight . In the hedge of [the lane]278-the lane there was a gate on which [he]73-lucian used to lean and look down south to where [the hill]268-the hill surged up so suddenly , [its]268-the hill summit defined on summer evenings not only by the rounded ramparts but by the ring of dense green foliage that marked the circle of oak trees . Higher up [the lane]278-the lane , on the way [he]73-lucian had come that Saturday afternoon , one could see the white walls of [[Morgan]75-annie 's farm]1668-morgan 's farm on [the hillside]311-the hillside to the north , and on the south there was the stile with the view of [[old Mrs. Gibbon]74-old mrs. gibbon 's cottage smoke]1670-old mrs. gibbon 's cottage smoke ; but down in [the hollow]1671-the hollow , looking over the gate , there was no hint of human work , except those green and antique battlements , on which the oaks stood in circle , guarding the inner wood . The ring of [the fort]1672-the fort drew [him]73-lucian with stronger fascination during that hot August weather . Standing , or as [[his]73-lucian headmaster]1673-his headmaster would have said , "[79-mr. taylor] mooning " by the gate , and looking into [that enclosed and secret valley]1674-that enclosed and secret valley , it seemed to [his]73-lucian fancy as if there were a halo about [the hill]268-the hill , an aureole that played like flame around it . One afternoon as [he]73-lucian gazed from [[his]73-lucian station]1676-his station by the gate the sheer sides and the swelling bulwarks were more than ever things of enchantment ; the green oak ring stood out against the sky as still and bright as in a picture , and [Lucian]73-lucian , in spite of [his]73-lucian respect for the law of trespass , slid over the gate . [The farmers]1677-the farmers and [[their]1677-the farmers men]1678-their men were busy on [the uplands]1679-the uplands with the harvest , and the adventure was irresistible . At first [he]73-lucian stole along by [the brook]1680-the brook in the shadow of [the alders]1681-the alders , where the grass and the flowers of wet meadows grew richly ; but as [he]73-lucian drew nearer to [the fort]1672-the fort , and [its]1672-the fort height now rose sheer above [him]73-lucian , [he]73-lucian left all shelter , and began desperately to mount . There was not a breath of wind ; the sunlight shone down on [the bare hillside]1683-the bare hillside ; the loud chirp of the grasshoppers was the only sound . It was a steep ascent and grew steeper as [the valley]270-the valley sank away . [He]73-lucian turned for a moment , and looked down towards [the stream which now seemed to wind remote between [the alders]1681-the alders]1685-the stream which now seemed to wind remote between the alders ; above [the valley]270-the valley there were small dark figures moving in [the cornfield]1688-the cornfield , and now and again there came the faint echo of a high - pitched voice singing through the air as on a wire . [He]73-lucian was wet with heat ; the sweat streamed off [his]73-lucian face , and [he]73-lucian could feel it trickling all over [his]73-lucian body . But above [him]73-lucian the green bastions rose defiant , and the dark ring of oaks promised coolness . [He]73-lucian pressed on , and higher , and at last began to crawl up the vallum , on hands and knees , grasping the turf and here and there the roots that had burst through the red earth . And then [he]73-lucian lay , panting with deep breaths , on the summit . Within [the fort]1672-the fort [it]1690-it was all dusky and cool and hollow ; it was as if [one]1691-one stood at the bottom of a great cup . Within , the wall seemed higher than without , and the ring of oaks curved up like a dark green vault . There were nettles growing thick and rank in the foss ; they looked different from the common nettles in [the lanes]1656-the lanes , and [Lucian]73-lucian , letting [his]73-lucian hand touch a leaf by accident , felt the sting burn like fire . Beyond [the ditch]1693-the ditch there was an undergrowth , a dense thicket of trees , stunted and old , crooked and withered by the winds into awkward and ugly forms ; beech and oak and hazel and ash and yew twisted and so shortened and deformed that each seemed , like the nettle , of no common kind . [He]73-lucian began to fight [his]73-lucian way through the ugly growth , stumbling and getting hard knocks from the rebound of twisted boughs . [His]73-lucian foot struck once or twice against something harder than wood , and looking down [he]73-lucian saw stones white with the leprosy of age , but still showing the work of the axe . And farther , the roots of the stunted trees gripped the foot - high relics of a wall ; and a round heap of fallen stones nourished rank , unknown herbs , that smelt poisonous . [The earth]333-the earth was black and unctuous , and bubbling under the feet , left no track behind . From it , in the darkest places where the shadow was thickest , swelled the growth of an abominable fungus , making the still air sick with its corrupt odor , and [he]73-lucian shuddered as [he]73-lucian felt the horrible thing pulped beneath [his]73-lucian feet . Then there was a gleam of sunlight , and as [he]73-lucian thrust the last boughs apart , [he]73-lucian stumbled into the open space in [the heart of [the camp]327-the camp]1695-the heart of the camp . [It]1697-it was [a lawn of sweet close turf in the center of the matted brake , of clean firm earth from which no shameful growth sprouted , and near the middle of [the glade]1699-the glade]1698-a lawn of sweet close turf in the center of the matted brake , of clean firm earth from which no shameful growth sprouted , and near the middle of the glade was a stump of a felled yew - tree , left untrimmed by [the woodman]1700-the woodman . [Lucian]73-lucian thought it must have been made for a seat ; a crooked bough through which a little sap still ran was a support for the back , and [he]73-lucian sat down and rested after [his]73-lucian toil . It was not really so comfortable a seat as one of the school forms , but the satisfaction was to find anything at all that would serve for a chair . [He]73-lucian sat there , still panting after the climb and [his]73-lucian struggle through [the dank and jungle - like thicket]1701-the dank and jungle - like thicket , and [he]73-lucian felt as if [he]73-lucian were growing hotter and hotter ; the sting of the nettle was burning [his]73-lucian hand , and the tingling fire seemed to spread all over [his]73-lucian body . Suddenly , [he]73-lucian knew that [he]73-lucian was alone . Not merely solitary ; that [he]73-lucian had often been amongst [the woods]331-the woods and deep in [the lanes]1656-the lanes ; but now it was a wholly different and a very strange sensation . [He]73-lucian thought of [the valley]270-the valley winding far below [him]73-lucian , [all [its]270-the valley fields]1705-all its fields by [the brook]1680-the brook green and peaceful and still , without path or track . Then [he]73-lucian had climbed the abrupt surge of [the hill]268-the hill , and passing [the green and swelling battlements]1708-the green and swelling battlements , [the ring of oaks]1709-the ring of oaks , and the matted thicket , had come to [the central space]1710-the central space . And behind there were , [he]73-lucian knew , [many desolate fields]1711-many desolate fields , [wild as common]1712-wild as common , untrodden , unvisited . [He]73-lucian was utterly alone . [He]73-lucian still grew hotter as [he]73-lucian sat on the stump , and at last lay down at full length on the soft grass , and more at [his]73-lucian ease felt the waves of heat pass over [his]73-lucian body . And then [he]73-lucian began to dream , to let [his]73-lucian fancies stray over half - imagined , delicious things , indulging a virgin mind in its wanderings . The hot air seemed to beat upon [him]73-lucian in palpable waves , and the nettle sting tingled and itched intolerably ; and [he]73-lucian was alone upon [the fairy hill]1713-the fairy hill , within the great mounds , within the ring of oaks , deep in the heart of the matted thicket . Slowly and timidly [he]73-lucian began to untie [his]73-lucian boots , fumbling with the laces , and glancing all the while on every side at the ugly misshapen trees that hedged [the lawn]1714-the lawn . Not a branch was straight , not one was free , but all were interlaced and grew one about another ; and just above ground , where the cankered stems joined the protuberant roots , there were forms that imitated the human shape , and faces and twining limbs that amazed [him]73-lucian . Green mosses were hair , and tresses were stark in grey lichen ; a twisted root swelled into a limb ; in the hollows of the rotted bark [he]73-lucian saw the masks of [men]1715-men . [His]73-lucian eyes were fixed and fascinated by the simulacra of the wood , and could not see [his]73-lucian hands , and so at last , and suddenly , it seemed , [he]73-lucian lay in the sunlight , beautiful with [his]73-lucian olive skin , dark haired , dark eyed , the gleaming bodily vision of [a strayed faun]1716-a strayed faun . Quick flames now quivered in the substance of [his]73-lucian nerves , hints of mysteries , secrets of life passed trembling through [his]73-lucian brain , unknown desires stung [him]73-lucian . As [he]73-lucian gazed across the turf and into the thicket , the sunshine seemed really to become green , and the contrast between the bright glow poured on [the lawn]1714-the lawn and the black shadow of [the brake]1650-the brake made an odd flickering light , in which all the grotesque postures of stem and root began to stir ; the wood was alive . The turf beneath [him]73-lucian heaved and sank as with the deep swell of [the sea]1719-the sea . [He]73-lucian fell asleep , and lay still on the grass , in the midst of [the thicket]1720-the thicket . [He]73-lucian found out afterwards that [he]73-lucian must have slept for nearly an hour . The shadows had changed when [he]73-lucian awoke ; [his]73-lucian senses came to [him]73-lucian with a sudden shock , and [he]73-lucian sat up and stared at [his]73-lucian bare limbs in stupid amazement . [He]73-lucian huddled on [his]73-lucian clothes and laced [his]73-lucian boots , wondering what folly had beset [him]73-lucian . Then , while [he]73-lucian stood indecisive , hesitating , [his]73-lucian brain a whirl of puzzled thought , [his]73-lucian body trembling , [his]73-lucian hands shaking ; as with electric heat , sudden remembrance possessed [him]73-lucian . A flaming blush shone red on [his]73-lucian cheeks , and glowed and thrilled through [his]73-lucian limbs . As [he]73-lucian awoke , a brief and slight breeze had stirred in a nook of the matted boughs , and there was a glinting that might have been the flash of sudden sunlight across shadow , and the branches rustled and murmured for a moment , perhaps at the wind 's passage . [He]73-lucian stretched out [his]73-lucian hands , and cried to [[his]73-lucian visitant]1721-his visitant to return ; [he]73-lucian entreated the dark eyes that had shone over [him]73-lucian , and the scarlet lips that had kissed [him]73-lucian . And then panic fear rushed into [his]73-lucian heart , and [he]73-lucian ran blindly , dashing through the wood . [He]73-lucian climbed the vallum , and looked out , crouching , lest [anybody]1722-anybody should see [him]73-lucian . Only the shadows were changed , and a breath of cooler air mounted from [the brook]1680-the brook ; [the fields]314-the fields were still and peaceful , the black figures moved , far away , amidst the corn , and the faint echo of the high - pitched voices sang thin and distant on the evening wind . Across [the stream]1725-the stream , in [the cleft on [the hill]268-the hill]1726-the cleft on the hill , opposite to [the fort]1672-the fort , the blue wood smoke stole up a spiral pillar from the chimney of [[old Mrs. Gibbon]74-old mrs. gibbon 's cottage]1729-old mrs. gibbon 's cottage . [He]73-lucian began to run full tilt down [the steep surge of [the hill]268-the hill]1730-the steep surge of the hill , and never stopped till [he]73-lucian was over the gate and in [the lane]278-the lane again . As [he]73-lucian looked back , down [the valley]270-the valley to the south , and saw the violent ascent , the green swelling bulwarks , and the dark ring of oaks ; the sunlight seemed to play about [the fort]1672-the fort with an aureole of flame . "[73-lucian] Where on earth have [you]407-you been all this time , [Lucian]73-lucian ? " said [[his]73-lucian cousin]1735-his cousin when [he]1735-his cousin got [home]308-home . "[73-lucian] Why , [you]407-you look quite ill . It is really madness of [you]407-you to go walking in such weather as this . [I]0-i wonder [you]407-you have n't got a sunstroke . And the tea must be nearly cold . [I]0-i could n't keep [[your]407-you father]408-your father waiting , [you]407-you know . " [He]73-lucian muttered something about being rather tired , and sat down to [his]73-lucian tea . It was not cold , for the "[0-i] cozy " had been put over the pot , but it was black and bitter strong , as [[his]73-lucian cousin]1735-his cousin expressed it . The draught was unpalatable , but it did [him]73-lucian good , and the thought came with great consolation that [he]73-lucian had only been asleep and dreaming queer , nightmarish dreams . [He]73-lucian shook off all [his]73-lucian fancies with resolution , and thought the loneliness of [the camp]327-the camp , and the burning sunlight , and possibly the nettle sting , which still tingled most abominably , must have been the only factors in [his]73-lucian farrago of impossible recollections . [He]73-lucian remembered that when [he]73-lucian had felt the sting , [he]73-lucian had seized a nettle with thick folds of [his]73-lucian handkerchief , and having twisted off a good length , and put it in [his]73-lucian pocket to show [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father . [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor was almost interested when [he]79-mr. taylor came in from [his]79-mr. taylor evening stroll about [the garden]1648-the garden and saw the specimen . "[73-lucian] Where did [you]409-you manage to come across that , [Lucian]73-lucian ? " [he]79-mr. taylor said . "[73-lucian] [You]409-you have n't been to [Caermaen]7-caermaen , have [you]409-you ? " "[409-you] No . [I]0-i got it in [the Roman fort]347-the roman fort by [the common]411-the common . " "[0-i] Oh , the twyn . [You]409-you must have been trespassing then . Do [you]409-you know what it is ? " "[409-you] No . [I]0-i thought it looked different from the common nettles . " "[0-i] Yes ; it 's [a Roman nettleâ€”arctic pilulifera]1741-a roman nettleâ€”arctic pilulifera . It 's a rare plant . [Burrows]88-dr. burrows says it 's to be found at [Caermaen]7-caermaen , but [I]412-the maid was never able to come across it . [I]412-the maid must add it to the flora of [the parish]1742-the parish . "[412-the maid] [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor had begun to compile a flora accompanied by a hortus siccus , but both stayed on high shelves dusty and fragmentary . [He]79-mr. taylor put the specimen on [his]79-mr. taylor desk , intending to fasten it in the book , but [the maid]412-the maid swept it away , dry and withered , in a day or two . [Lucian]73-lucian tossed and cried out in [his]73-lucian sleep that night , and the awakening in the morning was , in a measure , a renewal of the awakening in [the fort]1672-the fort . But the impression was not so strong , and in [a plain room]414-a plain room it seemed all delirium , a phantasmagoria . [He]73-lucian had to go down to [Caermaen]7-caermaen in the afternoon , for [Mrs. Dixon]91-mrs. dixon , [[the vicar]415-the vicar 's wife]416-the vicar 's wife , had " commanded "[416-the vicar 's wife] [his]73-lucian presence at tea . [Mr. Dixon]92-mr. dixon , though fat and short and clean shaven , ruddy of face , was [a safe man]417-a safe man , with no extreme views on anything . [He]92-mr. dixon " deplored "[92-mr. dixon] all extreme party convictions , and thought the great needs of [[our]418-our beloved Church]419-our beloved church were conciliation , moderation , and above all " amolgamation"â€”so[92-mr. dixon] [he]92-mr. dixon pronounced the word . [Mrs. Dixon]91-mrs. dixon was tall , imposing , splendid , well fitted for the Episcopal order , with gifts that would have shone at [the palace]420-the palace . There were [daughters]421-daughters , who studied German Literature , and thought [Miss Frances Ridley Havergal]93-miss frances ridley havergal wrote poetry , but [Lucian]73-lucian had no fear of [them]421-daughters ; [he]73-lucian dreaded [the boys]422-the boys . [Everybody]423-everybody said [they]422-the boys were [such fine , manly fellows]424-such fine , manly fellows , [such gentlemanly boys , with such a good manner]425-such gentlemanly boys , with such a good manner , sure to get on in [the world]286-the world . [Lucian]73-lucian had said " Bother ! "[73-lucian] in a very violent manner when the gracious invitation was conveyed to [him]73-lucian , but there was no getting out of it . [Miss Deacon]90-miss deacon did [her]90-miss deacon best to make [him]73-lucian look smart ; [his]73-lucian ties were all so disgraceful that [she]90-miss deacon had to supply the want with a narrow ribbon of a sky - blue tint ; and [she]90-miss deacon brushed [him]73-lucian so long and so violently that [he]73-lucian quite understood why a horse sometimes bites and sometimes kicks [the groom]427-the groom . [He]73-lucian set out between two and three in a gloomy frame of mind ; [he]73-lucian knew too well what spending the afternoon with [honest manly boys]428-honest manly boys meant . [He]73-lucian found the reality more lurid than [his]73-lucian anticipation . [The boys]422-the boys were in [the field]1629-the field , and the first remark [he]73-lucian heard when [he]73-lucian got in sight of [the group]431-the group was : " [Hullo]94-hullo , [Lucian]73-lucian , how much for the tie ? "[422-the boys] " Fine tie , "[432-a stranger] another , [a stranger]432-a stranger , observed . " [You]73-lucian bagged it from the kitten , did n't [you]73-lucian ? "[432-a stranger] Then [they]422-the boys made up a game of cricket , and [he]73-lucian was put in first . [He]73-lucian was l.b.w . in [his]73-lucian second over , so [they]422-the boys all said , and had to field for the rest of the afternoon . [Arthur Dixon]95-arthur dixon , who was about [his]95-arthur dixon own age , forgetting all the laws of hospitality , told [him]95-arthur dixon [he]95-arthur dixon was [a beastly muff]433-a beastly muff when [he]95-arthur dixon missed a catch , rather a difficult catch . [He]95-arthur dixon missed several catches , and it seemed as if [he]95-arthur dixon were always panting after balls , which , as [Edward Dixon]96-edward dixon said , [any fool]434-any fool , even [a baby]435-a baby , could have stopped . At last the game broke up , solely from [Lucian]73-lucian 's lack of skill , as [everybody]423-everybody declared . [Edward Dixon]96-edward dixon , who was thirteen , and had a swollen red face and a projecting eye , wanted to fight [him]95-arthur dixon for spoiling the game , and [the others]437-the others agreed that [he]95-arthur dixon funked the fight in a rather dirty manner . [The strange boy]438-the strange boy , who was called [De Carti]97-de carti , and was understood to be faintly related to [Lord De Carti of M'Carthytown]97-de carti , said openly that [the fellows at [[his]438-the strange boy place]440-his place]439-the fellows at his place would n't stand such a sneak for five minutes . So the afternoon passed off very pleasantly indeed , till it was time to go into [the vicarage]441-the vicarage for weak tea , homemade cake , and unripe plums . [He]438-the strange boy got away at last . As [he]438-the strange boy went out at the gate , [he]438-the strange boy heard [De Carti]97-de carti 's final observation : " [We]1743-we like to dress well at [[our]1743-we place]1744-our place . [[His]438-the strange boy governor]1745-his governor must be beastly poor to let [him]438-the strange boy go about like that . D'y ' see [his]438-the strange boy trousers are all ragged at heel ? Is [old Taylor]79-mr. taylor [a gentleman]1746-a gentleman ? "[97-de carti] It had been a very gentlemanly afternoon , but there was a certain relief when [the vicarage]441-the vicarage was far behind , and the evening smoke of [the little town]443-the little town , once [the glorious capital of Siluria]444-the glorious capital of siluria , hung haze - like over [the ragged roofs]445-the ragged roofs and mingled with the river mist . [He]438-the strange boy looked down from the height of [the road]287-the road on [the huddled houses]447-the huddled houses , saw the points of light start out suddenly from [the cottages on [the hillside beyond]449-the hillside beyond]448-the cottages on the hillside beyond , and gazed at [the long lovely valley]450-the long lovely valley fading in the twilight , till the darkness came and all that remained was [the somber ridge of [the forest]452-the forest]451-the somber ridge of the forest . The way was pleasant through [the solemn scented lane]453-the solemn scented lane , with glimpses of [dim country]454-dim country , the vague mystery of night overshadowing [the woods and meadows]455-the woods and meadows . A warm wind blew gusts of odor from [the meadowsweet]456-the meadowsweet by [the brook]1680-the brook , now and then bee and beetle span homeward through the air , booming a deep note as from a great organ far away , and from the verge of the wood came the " who - oo , who - oo , who - oo "[461-their] of the owls , a wild strange sound that mingled with the whirr and rattle of the night - jar , deep in the bracken . The moon swam up through the films of misty cloud , and hung , a golden glorious lantern , in mid - air ; and , set in the dusky hedge , the little green fires of the glowworms appeared . [He]438-the strange boy sauntered slowly up [the lane]278-the lane , drinking in the religion of the scene , and thinking [the country]459-the country by night as mystic and wonderful as [a dimly - lit cathedral]460-a dimly - lit cathedral . [He]438-the strange boy had quite forgotten [the " manly young fellows]1747-the " manly young fellows "[341-his father] and [their]461-their sports , and only wished as [the land]462-the land began to shimmer and gleam in the moonlight that [he]438-the strange boy knew by some medium of words or color how to represent the loveliness about [his]438-the strange boy way . " Had a pleasant evening , [Lucian]73-lucian ? "[341-his father] said [[his]438-the strange boy father]341-his father when [he]341-his father came in . " Yes , [I]1635-the parson had a nice walk [home]308-home . Oh , in the afternoon [we]1749-we played cricket . [I]1635-the parson did n't care for it much . There was [a boy named [De Carti]97-de carti [there]1751-there]1750-a boy named de carti there ; [he]1750-a boy named de carti there is staying with [the Dixons]98-the dixons . [Mrs. Dixon]91-mrs. dixon whispered to [me]1635-the parson when [we]1749-we were going in to tea , ' [He]1750-a boy named de carti there 's [a second cousin of [Lord De Carti]97-de carti 's]1752-a second cousin of lord de carti 's , ' and [she]91-mrs. dixon looked quite grave as if [she]91-mrs. dixon were in [church]1624-church . "[1635-the parson] [The parson]1635-the parson grinned grimly and lit [his]1635-the parson old pipe . " [[Baron De Carti]99-baron de carti 's great - grandfather]1754-baron de carti 's great - grandfather was [a Dublin attorney]1755-a dublin attorney , "[1635-the parson] [he]1635-the parson remarked . " Which [his]1754-baron de carti 's great - grandfather name was [Jeremiah M'Carthy]100-jeremiah m'carthy . [[His]1754-baron de carti 's great - grandfather prejudiced fellow - citizens]1756-his prejudiced fellow - citizens called [him]1754-baron de carti 's great - grandfather [the Unjust Steward]1757-the unjust steward , also [the Bloody Attorney]1758-the bloody attorney , and [I]376-the bishop believe that ' to hell with [M'Carthy]100-jeremiah m'carthy ' was quite a popular cry about the time of the Union . "[376-the bishop] [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor was [a man of very wide and irregular reading and a tenacious memory]465-a man of very wide and irregular reading and a tenacious memory ; [he]79-mr. taylor often used to wonder why [he]79-mr. taylor had not risen in [the Church]8-the church . [He]79-mr. taylor had once told [Mr. Dixon]92-mr. dixon a singular and drolatique anecdote concerning [the bishop]376-the bishop 's college days , and [he]79-mr. taylor never discovered why [the prelate]467-the prelate did not bow according to [his]467-the prelate custom when the name of [Taylor]79-mr. taylor was called at the next visitation . [Some people]468-some people said the reason was lighted candles , but that was impossible , as [the Reverend]469-the reverend and [Honorable Smallwood Stafford]101-honorable smallwood stafford , [[Lord Beamys]102-lord beamys 's son , who had a cure of souls in [the cathedral city]471-the cathedral city]470-lord beamys 's son , who had a cure of souls in the cathedral city , was well known to burn no end of candles , and with [him]470-lord beamys 's son , who had a cure of souls in the cathedral city [the bishop]376-the bishop was on the best of terms . Indeed [the bishop]376-the bishop often stayed at [Coplesey]9-coplesey ( pronounced " [Copsey "[91-mrs. dixon] ) Hall]10-copsey " ) hall , [[Lord Beamys]102-lord beamys 's place in [the west]475-the west]474-lord beamys 's place in the west . [Lucian]73-lucian had mentioned the name of [De Carti]99-baron de carti with intention , and had perhaps exaggerated a little [Mrs. Dixon]91-mrs. dixon 's respectful manner . [He]73-lucian knew such incidents cheered [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father , who could never look at [these subjects]477-these subjects from a proper point of view , and , as [people]478-people said , sometimes made the strangest remarks for [a clergyman]479-a clergyman . This irreverent way of treating serious things was one of the great bonds between [father]480-father and [son]481-son , but it tended to increase [their]482-their isolation . [People]478-people said [they]478-people would often have liked to asked [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor to garden - parties , and tea - parties , and other cheap entertainments , if only [he]79-mr. taylor had not been such [an extreme man and so queer]484-an extreme man and so queer . Indeed , a year before , [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor had gone to a garden - party at [the Castle]485-the castle , [Caermaen]7-caermaen , and had made such fun of [the bishop]376-the bishop 's recent address on missions to [the Portuguese]487-the portuguese , that [the Gervases]103-the gervases and [Dixons]98-the dixons and all who heard [him]79-mr. taylor were quite shocked and annoyed . And , as [Mrs. Meyrick of Lanyravon]104-mrs. meyrick of lanyravon observed , [his]79-mr. taylor black coat was perfectly green with age ; so on the whole [the Gervases]103-the gervases did not like to invite [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor again . As for [the son]488-the son , [nobody]1639-nobody cared to have [him]488-the son ; [Mrs. Dixon]91-mrs. dixon , as [she]91-mrs. dixon said to [[her]91-mrs. dixon husband]490-her husband , really asked [him]488-the son out of charity . " [I]91-mrs. dixon am afraid [he]488-the son seldom gets a real meal at [home]308-home , "[91-mrs. dixon] [she]91-mrs. dixon remarked , " so [I]73-lucian thought [he]488-the son would enjoy a good wholesome tea for once in a way . But [he]488-the son is such [an unsatisfactory boy]1760-an unsatisfactory boy , [he]488-the son would only have one slice of that nice plain cake , and [I]73-lucian could n't get [him]488-the son to take more than two plums . They were really quite ripe too , and [boys]1761-boys are usually so fond of fruit . "[73-lucian] Thus [Lucian]73-lucian was forced to spend [his]73-lucian holidays chiefly in [his]73-lucian own company , and make the best [he]73-lucian could of the ripe peaches on the south wall of [the rectory garden]491-the rectory garden . There was a certain corner where the heat of that hot August seemed concentrated , reverberated from one wall to the other , and [here]492-here [he]73-lucian liked to linger of mornings , when the mists were still thick in [the valleys]493-the valleys , " mooning , "[73-lucian] meditating , extending [his]73-lucian walk from [the quince]494-the quince to [the medlar]495-the medlar and back again , beside the moldering walls of mellowed brick . [He]73-lucian was full of a certain wonder and awe , not unmixed with a swell of strange exultation , and wished more and more to be alone , to think over that wonderful afternoon within [the fort]1672-the fort . In spite of [himself]73-lucian the impression was fading ; [he]73-lucian could not understand that feeling of mad panic terror that drove [him]73-lucian through [the thicket]1720-the thicket and down [the steep hillside]498-the steep hillside ; yet , [he]73-lucian had experienced so clearly the physical shame and reluctance of the flesh ; [he]73-lucian recollected that for a few seconds after [his]73-lucian awakening the sight of [his]73-lucian own body had made [him]73-lucian shudder and writhe as if it had suffered some profoundest degradation . [He]73-lucian saw before [him]73-lucian a vision of two forms ; [a faun with tingling and prickling flesh]499-a faun with tingling and prickling flesh lay expectant in the sunlight , and there was also the likeness of [a miserable shamed boy , standing with trembling body and shaking , unsteady hands]500-a miserable shamed boy , standing with trembling body and shaking , unsteady hands . It was all confused , a procession of blurred images , now of rapture and ecstasy , and now of terror and shame , floating in a light that was altogether phantasmal and unreal . [He]73-lucian dared not approach [the fort]1672-the fort again ; [he]73-lucian lingered in [the road to [Caermaen]7-caermaen that passed behind [it]1672-the fort]502-the road to caermaen that passed behind it , but a mile away , and separated by [the wild land]503-the wild land and [a strip of wood]504-a strip of wood from [the towering battlements]505-the towering battlements . Here [he]73-lucian was looking over a gate one day , doubtful and wondering , when [he]73-lucian heard a heavy step behind [him]73-lucian , and glancing round quickly saw it was [[old Morgan]75-annie of [the White House]319-the white house]506-old morgan of the white house . " Good afternoon , [Master Lucian]73-lucian , "[73-lucian] [he]73-lucian began . " [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor pretty well , [I]73-lucian suppose ? [I]73-lucian be goin' to [the house]1762-the house a minute ; [the men in [the fields]314-the fields]1763-the men in the fields are wantin ' some more cider . Would [you]73-lucian come and taste a drop of cider , [Master Lucian]73-lucian ? It 's very good , [sir]1765-sir , indeed . "[1766-tiles with raised initials and a date.â€”i.m. , 1684] [Lucian]73-lucian did not want any cider , but [he]73-lucian thought it would please [old Morgan]75-annie if [he]73-lucian took some , so [he]73-lucian said [he]73-lucian should like to taste the cider very much indeed . [Morgan]75-annie was [a sturdy , thick - set old man of the ancient stock]508-a sturdy , thick - set old man of the ancient stock ; [a stiff churchman]509-a stiff churchman , who breakfasted regularly on fat broth and Caerphilly cheese in the fashion of [[his]508-a sturdy , thick - set old man of the ancient stock ancestors]510-his ancestors ; hot , spiced elder wine was for winter nights , and gin for festal seasons . [The farm]511-the farm had always been [the freehold of [the family]513-the family]512-the freehold of the family , and when [Lucian]73-lucian , in the wake of [the yeoman]514-the yeoman , passed through [the deep porch]515-the deep porch by the oaken door , down into [the long dark kitchen]516-the long dark kitchen , [he]73-lucian felt as though the seventeenth century still lingered on . One mullioned window , set deep in the sloping wall , gave all the light there was through quarries of thick glass in which there were whorls and circles , so that the lapping rose - branch and [the garden]1648-the garden and [the fields beyond]518-the fields beyond were distorted to the sight . Two heavy beams , oaken but whitewashed , ran across the ceiling ; a little glow of fire sparkled in the great fireplace , and a curl of blue smoke fled up the cavern of the chimney . [Here]492-here was the genuine chimney - corner of [[our]520-our fathers]521-our fathers ; there were seats on each side of the fireplace where [one]1691-one could sit snug and sheltered on December nights , warm and merry in the blazing light , and listen to the battle of the storm , and hear the flame spit and hiss at the falling snowflakes . At the back of the fire were great blackened [tiles with raised initials and a date.â€”I.M. , 1684]1766-tiles with raised initials and a date.â€”i.m. , 1684 . "[75-annie] Sit down , [Master Lucian]73-lucian , sit down , [sir]1765-sir , " said [Morgan]75-annie . "[75-annie] [Annie]75-annie , " [he]1765-sir called through one of the numerous doors , "[75-annie] here 's [Master Lucian]73-lucian , [the parson]1635-the parson , would like a drop of cider . Fetch a jug , will [you]75-annie , directly ? " "[480-father] Very well , [father]480-father , " came the voice from [the dairy]1767-the dairy and presently [the girl]1768-the girl entered , wiping the jug [she]1768-the girl held . In [his]73-lucian boyish way [Lucian]73-lucian had been a good deal disturbed by [Annie Morgan]75-annie ; [he]73-lucian could see [her]75-annie on Sundays from [his]73-lucian seat in [church]1624-church , and [her]75-annie skin , curiously pale , [her]75-annie lips that seemed as though they were stained with some brilliant pigment , [her]75-annie black hair , and the quivering black eyes , gave [him]73-lucian odd fancies which [he]73-lucian had hardly shaped to [himself]73-lucian . [Annie]75-annie had grown into [a woman]1770-a woman in three years , and [he]73-lucian was still [a boy]1771-a boy . [She]75-annie came into [the kitchen]1772-the kitchen , curtsying and smiling . "[1765-sir] Good - day , [Master Lucian]73-lucian , and how is [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor , [sir]1765-sir ? " "[0-i] Pretty well , thank [you]1765-sir . [I]0-i hope [you]1765-sir are well . " "[0-i] Nicely , [sir]1765-sir , thank [you]1765-sir . How nice [your]1765-sir voice do sound in [church]1624-church , [Master Lucian]73-lucian , to be sure . [I]0-i was telling [father]480-father about it last Sunday . " [Lucian]73-lucian grinned and felt uncomfortable , and [the girl]1768-the girl set down the jug on the round table and brought a glass from the dresser . [She]75-annie bent close over [him]73-lucian as [she]75-annie poured out the green oily cider , fragrant of [the orchard]1774-the orchard ; [her]75-annie hand touched [his]73-lucian shoulder for a moment , and [she]75-annie said , "[0-i] [I]0-i beg [your]1765-sir pardon , [sir]1765-sir , " very prettily . [He]73-lucian looked up eagerly at [her]75-annie face ; the black eyes , a little oval in shape , were shining , and the lips smiled . [Annie]75-annie wore a plain dress of some black stuff , open at the throat ; [her]75-annie skin was beautiful . For a moment the ghost of a fancy hovered unsubstantial in [his]73-lucian mind ; and then [Annie]75-annie curtsied as [she]75-annie handed [him]73-lucian the cider , and replied to [his]73-lucian thanks with , "[1765-sir] And welcome kindly , [sir]1765-sir . " The drink was really good ; not thin , nor sweet , but round and full and generous , with a fine yellow flame twinkling through the green when one held it up to the light . It was like a stray sunbeam hovering on the grass in [a deep orchard]1775-a deep orchard , and [he]73-lucian swallowed the glassful with relish , and had some more , warmly commending it . [Mr. Morgan]105-mr. morgan was touched . "[1765-sir] [I]0-i see [you]1765-sir do know a good thing , [sir]1765-sir , " [he]0-i said . "[0-i] Is , indeed , now , it 's good stuff , though it 's [my]0-i own makin ' . [[My]0-i old grandfather]533-my old grandfather [he]533-my old grandfather planted the trees in the time of the wars , and [he]533-my old grandfather was a very good judge of an apple in [his]533-my old grandfather day and generation . And [a famous grafter]534-a famous grafter [he]533-my old grandfather was , to be sure . [You]535-you will never see no swelling in the trees [he]533-my old grandfather grafted at all whatever . Now there 's [James Morris]106-james morris , [Penyrhaul]107-penyrhaul , [he]533-my old grandfather 's [a famous grafter]534-a famous grafter , too , and yet them Redstreaks [he]533-my old grandfather grafted for [me]0-i five year ago , they be all swollen - like below the graft already . Would [you]535-you like to taste [a Blemmin pippin]537-a blemmin pippin , now , [Master Lucian]73-lucian ? there be a few left in [the loft]538-the loft , [I]0-i believe . " [Lucian]73-lucian said [he]73-lucian should like an apple very much , and [the farmer]1776-the farmer went out by another door , and [Annie]75-annie stayed in [the kitchen]1772-the kitchen talking . [She]75-annie said [Mrs. Trevor]108-mrs. trevor , [[her]75-annie married sister]1778-her married sister , was coming to [them]1779-them soon to spend a few days . "[540-a beautiful baby] [She]539-she 's got such [a beautiful baby]540-a beautiful baby , " said [Annie]75-annie , "[1765-sir] and [he]540-a beautiful baby 's quite sensible - like already , though [he]540-a beautiful baby 's only nine months old . [Mary]76-mary would like to see [you]73-lucian , [sir]1765-sir , if [you]73-lucian would be so kind as to step in ; that is , if it 's not troubling [you]73-lucian at all , [Master Lucian]73-lucian .
