"[0-i] [I]0-i was first in [my]0-i form last term . " "[73-lucian] Fancy ! To think of that ! D'you hear , [father]480-father , what [a scholar]545-a scholar [Master Lucian]73-lucian be getting ? " "[0-i] [He]73-lucian be [a rare grammarian]546-a rare grammarian , [I]0-i 'm sure , " said [the farmer]1776-the farmer . "[73-lucian] [You]73-lucian do take after [[your]73-lucian father]408-your father , [sir]1765-sir ; [I]0-i always do say that [nobody]1639-nobody have got such a good deliverance in the pulpit . " [Lucian]73-lucian did not find the Blenheim Orange as good as the cider , but [he]73-lucian ate it with all the appearance of relish , and put another , with thanks , in [his]73-lucian pocket . [He]73-lucian thanked [the farmer]1776-the farmer again when [he]73-lucian got up to go ; and [Annie]75-annie curtsied and smiled , and wished [him]73-lucian good - day , and welcome , kindly . [Lucian]73-lucian heard [her]75-annie saying to [[her]75-annie father]1783-her father as [he]73-lucian went out what [a nice - mannered young gentleman [he]73-lucian was getting]1784-a nice - mannered young gentleman he was getting , to be sure ; and [he]73-lucian went on [his]73-lucian way , thinking that [Annie]75-annie was really very pretty , and speculating as to whether [he]73-lucian would have the courage to kiss [her]75-annie , if [they]1785-they met in [a dark lane]1786-a dark lane . [He]73-lucian was quite sure [she]75-annie would only laugh , and say , "[73-lucian] Oh , [Master Lucian]73-lucian ! " For many months [he]73-lucian had occasional fits of recollection , both cold and hot ; but the bridge of time , gradually lengthening , made those dreadful and delicious images grow more and more indistinct , till at last [they]1785-they all passed into that wonderland which [a youth]1787-a youth looks back upon in amazement , not knowing why this used to be a symbol of terror or that of joy . At the end of each term [he]73-lucian would come [home]308-home and find [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father a little more despondent , and harder to cheer even for a moment ; and the wall paper and the furniture grew more and more dingy and shabby . The two cats , loved and ancient beasts , that [he]73-lucian remembered when [he]73-lucian was quite [a little boy]1790-a little boy , before [he]73-lucian went to [school]374-school , died miserably , one after the other . [Old Polly]76-mary , the pony , at last fell down in [the stable]1792-the stable from the weakness of old age , and had to be killed there ; the battered old trap ran no longer along [the well - remembered lanes]1793-the well - remembered lanes . There was long meadow grass on [the lawn]1714-the lawn , and the trained fruit trees on the wall had got quite out of hand . At last , when [Lucian]73-lucian was seventeen , [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father was obliged to take [him]73-lucian from [school]374-school ; [he]73-lucian could no longer afford the fees . This was the sorry ending of many hopes , and dreams of a double - first , a fellowship , distinction and glory that [the poor parson]1797-the poor parson had long entertained for [[his]1797-the poor parson son]1798-his son , and [the two]1799-the two moped together , in [the shabby room]1800-the shabby room , one on each side of the sulky fire , thinking of dead days and finished plans , and seeing a grey future in the years that advanced towards them . At one time there seemed some chance of [a distant relative]1801-a distant relative coming forward to [Lucian]73-lucian 's assistance ; and indeed it was quite settled that [he]73-lucian should go up to [London]11-london with certain definite aims . [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor told the good news to [his]79-mr. taylor acquaintancesâ€”his[91-mrs. dixon] coat was too green now for any pretence of friendship ; and [Lucian]73-lucian [himself]73-lucian spoke of [his]73-lucian plans to [Burrows]88-dr. burrows [the doctor]550-the doctor and [Mr. Dixon]92-mr. dixon , and [one or two others]551-one or two others . Then the whole scheme fell through , and [the parson]1635-the parson and [[his]1635-the parson son]1798-his son suffered much sympathy . [People]478-people , of course , had to say [they]478-people were sorry , but in reality the news was received with high spirits , with the joy with which one sees a stone , as it rolls down a steep place , give yet another bounding leap towards the pool beneath . [Mrs. Dixon]91-mrs. dixon heard the pleasant tidings from [Mrs. Colley]109-mrs. colley , who came in to talk about [the Mothers]110-the mothers ' Meeting and [the Band of Hope]555-the band of hope . [Mrs. Dixon]91-mrs. dixon was nursing [little Athelwig]111-little athelwig , or some such name , at the time , and made many affecting observations on the general righteousness with which [the world]286-the world was governed . Indeed , [poor Lucian]73-lucian 's disappointment seemed distinctly to increase [her]91-mrs. dixon faith in the Divine Order , as if it had been some example in [[Butler]112-butler 's Analogy]12-butler 's analogy . " Are n't [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor 's views very extreme ? "[490-her husband] [she]91-mrs. dixon said to [[her]91-mrs. dixon husband]490-her husband the same evening . " [I]91-mrs. dixon am afraid they are , "[91-mrs. dixon] [he]490-her husband replied . " [I]91-mrs. dixon was quite grieved at the last Diocesan Conference at the way in which [he]79-mr. taylor spoke . [The dear old bishop]1802-the dear old bishop had given an address on Auricular Confession ; [he]79-mr. taylor was forced to do so , [you]1803-you know , after what had happened , and [I]91-mrs. dixon must say that [I]91-mrs. dixon never felt prouder of [[our]1804-our beloved Church]419-our beloved church . "[91-mrs. dixon] [Mr. Dixon]92-mr. dixon told all the Homeric story of the conference , reciting the achievements of [the champions]558-the champions , " deploring "[91-mrs. dixon] this and applauding that . It seemed that [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor had had the audacity to quote authorities which [the bishop]376-the bishop could not very well repudiate , though [they]560-they were directly opposed to the " safe "[91-mrs. dixon] Episcopal pronouncement . [Mrs. Dixon]91-mrs. dixon of course was grieved ; it was " sad "[91-mrs. dixon] to think of [a clergyman]479-a clergyman behaving so shamefully . " But [you]1803-you know , [dear]1625-dear , "[91-mrs. dixon] [she]91-mrs. dixon proceeded , " [I]91-mrs. dixon have been thinking about [that unfortunate Taylor boy]1807-that unfortunate taylor boy and [his]1807-that unfortunate taylor boy disappointments , and after what [you]1803-you 've just told [me]91-mrs. dixon , [I]91-mrs. dixon am sure it 's some kind of judgment on [them]1808-them both . Has [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor forgotten the vows [he]79-mr. taylor took at [his]79-mr. taylor ordination ? But do n't [you]1803-you think , [dear]1625-dear , [I]91-mrs. dixon am right , and that [he]79-mr. taylor has been punished : ' The sins of [the fathers]1810-the fathers ' ? "[91-mrs. dixon] Somehow or other [Lucian]73-lucian divined the atmosphere of threatenings and judgments , and shrank more and more from [the small society of [the countryside]563-the countryside]562-the small society of the countryside . For [his]73-lucian part , when [he]73-lucian was not " mooning "[73-lucian] in [the beloved fields and woods of happy memory]564-the beloved fields and woods of happy memory , [he]73-lucian shut [himself]73-lucian up with books , reading whatever could be found on the shelves , and amassing a store of incongruous and obsolete knowledge . Long did [he]73-lucian linger with [the men of the seventeenth century]565-the men of the seventeenth century ; delaying [the gay sunlit streets with [Pepys]113-pepys]566-the gay sunlit streets with pepys , and listening to the charmed sound of the Restoration Revel ; roaming by [peaceful streams with]567-peaceful streams with [Izaak Walton]114-izaak walton , and [the great Catholic divines]568-the great catholic divines ; enchanted with the portrait of [Herbert]115-herbert [the loving ascetic]569-the loving ascetic ; awed by the mystic breath of [Crashaw]116-crashaw . Then [the cavalier poets]570-the cavalier poets sang [their]570-the cavalier poets gallant songs ; and [Herrick]117-herrick made [Dean]118-dean Prior magic ground by the holy incantation of a verse . And in the old proverbs and homely sayings of the time [he]73-lucian found the good and beautiful English life , a time full of grace and dignity and rich merriment . [He]73-lucian dived deeper and deeper into [his]73-lucian books ; [he]73-lucian had taken all obsolescence to be [[his]73-lucian province]571-his province ; in [his]73-lucian disgust at the stupid usual questions , " Will it pay ? "[73-lucian] " What good is it ? "[120-mr. vaughan] and so forth , [he]73-lucian would only read what was uncouth and useless . The strange pomp and symbolism of [the Cabala]13-the cabala , with its hint of more terrible things ; the Rosicrucian mysteries of [Fludd]119-fludd , the enigmas of [Vaughan]120-mr. vaughan , dreams of alchemistsâ€”all these were [his]73-lucian delight . Such were [[his]73-lucian companions]1811-his companions , with [the hills]1660-the hills and [hanging woods]1813-hanging woods , [the brooks]1814-the brooks and [lonely waterpools]1815-lonely waterpools ; books , the thoughts of books , the stirrings of imagination , all fused into one phantasy by the magic of [the outland country]1816-the outland country . [He]73-lucian held [himself]73-lucian aloof from the walls of [the fort]1672-the fort ; [he]73-lucian was content to see [the heaped mounds]1818-the heaped mounds , the violent height with [faerie bulwarks]1819-faerie bulwarks , from the gate in [the lane]278-the lane , and to leave all within the ring of oaks in the mystery of [[his]73-lucian boyhood]1821-his boyhood 's vision . [He]73-lucian professed to laugh at [himself]73-lucian and at [his]73-lucian fancies of that hot August afternoon , when sleep came to [him]73-lucian within the thicket , but in [his]73-lucian heart of hearts there was something that never fadedâ€”something[341-his father] that glowed like the red glint of a gypsy 's fire seen from afar across [the hills]1660-the hills and mists of the night , and known to be burning in [a wild land]573-a wild land . Sometimes , when [he]574-he was sunken in [his]574-he books , the flame of delight shot up , and showed [him]574-he [a whole province and continent of [his]574-he nature]575-a whole province and continent of his nature , all shining and aglow ; and in the midst of the exultation and triumph [he]574-he would draw back , a little afraid . [He]574-he had become ascetic in [his]574-he studious and melancholy isolation , and the vision of such ecstasies frightened [him]574-he . [He]574-he began to write a little ; at first very tentatively and feebly , and then with more confidence . [He]574-he showed some of [his]574-he verses to [[his]574-he father]341-his father , who told [him]574-he with a sigh that [he]574-he had once hoped to writeâ€”in the old days at [Oxford]14-oxford , [he]574-he added . "[341-his father] They are very nicely done , " said [the parson]1635-the parson ; "[0-i] but [I]0-i 'm afraid [you]574-he wo n't find [anybody]1722-anybody to print them , [[my]0-i boy]578-my boy . " So [he]574-he pottered on ; reading everything , imitating what struck [his]574-he fancy , attempting the effect of the classic meters in English verse , trying [his]574-he hand at a masque , a Restoration comedy , forming impossible plans for books which rarely got beyond half a dozen lines on a sheet of paper ; beset with splendid fancies which refused to abide before the pen . But the vain joy of conception was not altogether vain , for it gave [him]574-he some armor about [his]574-he heart . The months went by , monotonous , and sometimes blotted with despair . [He]574-he wrote and planned and filled the waste - paper basket with hopeless efforts . Now and then [he]574-he sent verses or prose articles to magazines , in pathetic ignorance of the trade . [He]574-he felt the immense difficulty of the career of literature without clearly understanding it ; the battle was happily in a mist , so that the host of [the enemy]1823-the enemy , terribly arrayed , was to some extent hidden . Yet there was enough of difficulty to appall ; from following the intricate course of little nameless brooks , from [hushed twilight woods]1824-hushed twilight woods , from the vision of [the mountains]1825-the mountains , and the breath of the great wind , passing from deep to deep , [he]574-he would come [home]308-home filled with thoughts and emotions , mystic fancies which [he]574-he yearned to translate into the written word . And the result of the effort seemed always to be bathos ! Wooden sentences , a portentous stilted style , obscurity , and awkwardness clogged the pen ; it seemed impossible to win the great secret of language ; the stars glittered only in the darkness , and vanished away in clearer light . The periods of despair were often long and heavy , the victories very few and trifling ; night after night [he]574-he sat writing after [[his]574-he father]341-his father had knocked out [his]574-he last pipe , filling a page with difficulty in an hour , and usually forced to thrust the stuff away in despair , and go unhappily to bed , conscious that after all [his]574-he labor [he]574-he had done nothing . And these were moments when the accustomed vision of [the land]462-the land alarmed [him]574-he , and [the wild domed hills and darkling woods]1829-the wild domed hills and darkling woods seemed symbols of some terrible secret in the inner life of that strangerâ€”himself[579-he] . Sometimes when [he]579-he was deep in [his]579-he books and papers , sometimes on a lonely walk , sometimes amidst the tiresome chatter of [Caermaen]7-caermaen " society , "[589-the firm] [he]579-he would thrill with a sudden sense of awful hidden things , and there ran that quivering flame through [his]579-he nerves that brought back the recollection of the matted thicket , and that earlier appearance of the bare black boughs enwrapped with flames . Indeed , though [he]579-he avoided [the solitary lane]580-the solitary lane , and the sight of the sheer height , with [its]580-the solitary lane ring of oaks and molded mounds , the image of [it]580-the solitary lane grew more intense as the symbol of certain hints and suggestions . The exultant and insurgent flesh seemed to have its temple and castle within those olden walls , and [he]579-he longed with all [his]579-he heart to escape , to set [himself]579-he free in [the wilderness of [London]11-london]581-the wilderness of london , and to be secure amidst the murmur of [modern streets]582-modern streets . [Lucian]73-lucian was growing really anxious about [his]73-lucian manuscript . [He]73-lucian had gained enough experience at twenty - three to know that [editors]583-editors and [publishers]584-publishers must not be hurried ; but [his]73-lucian book had been lying at [[Messrs Beit]121-messrs beit 's office]585-messrs beit 's office for more than three months . For six weeks [he]73-lucian had not dared to expect an answer , but afterwards life had become agonizing . Every morning , at post - time , [the poor wretch]586-the poor wretch nearly choked with anxiety to know whether [his]73-lucian sentence had arrived , and the rest of the day was racked with alternate pangs of hope and despair . Now and then [he]73-lucian was almost assured of success ; conning over these painful and eager pages in memory , [he]73-lucian found parts that were admirable , while again , [his]73-lucian inexperience reproached [him]73-lucian , and [he]73-lucian feared [he]73-lucian had written a raw and awkward book , wholly unfit for print . Then [he]73-lucian would compare what [he]73-lucian remembered of it with notable magazine articles and books praised by [reviewers]587-reviewers , and fancy that after all there might be good points in the thing ; [he]73-lucian could not help liking the first chapter for instance . Perhaps the letter might come tomorrow . So it went on ; week after week of sick torture made more exquisite by such gleams of hope ; it was as if [he]73-lucian were stretched in anguish on the rack , and the pain relaxed and kind words spoken now and again by [the tormentors]588-the tormentors , and then once more the grinding pang and burning agony . At last [he]73-lucian could bear suspense no longer , and [he]73-lucian wrote to [Messrs Beit]121-messrs beit , inquiring in a humble manner whether the manuscript had arrived in safety . [The firm]589-the firm replied in a very polite letter , expressing regret that [[their]589-the firm reader]590-their reader had been suffering from a cold in the head , and had therefore been unable to send in [his]590-their reader report . A final decision was promised in a week 's time , and the letter ended with apologies for the delay and a hope that [he]73-lucian had suffered no inconvenience . Of course the " final decision "[73-lucian] did not come at the end of the week , but the book was returned at the end of three weeks , with a circular thanking [the author]591-the author for [his]73-lucian kindness in submitting the manuscript , and regretting that [the firm]589-the firm did not see [their]589-the firm way to producing it . [He]73-lucian felt relieved ; the operation that [he]73-lucian had dreaded and deprecated for so long was at last over , and [he]73-lucian would no longer grow sick of mornings when the letters were brought in . [He]73-lucian took [his]73-lucian parcel to the sunny corner of [the garden]1648-the garden , where the old wooden seat stood sheltered from the biting March winds . [Messrs Beit]121-messrs beit had put in with the circular one of [their]589-the firm short lists , a neat booklet , headed : [Messrs Beit]121-messrs beit & Co. 's Recent Publications . [He]73-lucian settled [himself]73-lucian comfortably on the seat , lit [his]73-lucian pipe , and began to read : " A Bad Un to Beat : a Novel of Sporting Life , by [the Honorable Mrs. Scudamore Runnymede]122-the honorable mrs. scudamore runnymede , [author of Yoicks]1830-author of yoicks , With the Mudshire Pack , [The Sportleigh Stables]1831-the sportleigh stables , etc . , etc . , 3 vols . At [all Libraries]1832-all libraries . "[73-lucian] The Press , it seemed , pronounced this to be a " charming book . [Mrs. Runnymede]122-the honorable mrs. scudamore runnymede has wit and humor enough to furnish forth half - a - dozen ordinary sporting novels . "[594-the review] " Told with the sparkle and vivacity of a past - mistress in the art of novel writing , "[595-this young person] said [the Review]594-the review ; while [Miranda]123-miranda , of [Smart Society]15-smart society , positively bubbled with enthusiasm . " [You]1833-you must forgive [me]595-this young person , [Aminta]124-aminta , "[595-this young person] wrote [this young person]595-this young person , " if [I]602-the reviewer have not sent the description [I]602-the reviewer promised of [Madame Lulu]125-madame lulu 's new creations and [others of that ilk]1834-others of that ilk . [I]602-the reviewer must a tale unfold ; [Tom]85-tom brown came in yesterday and began to rave about [the Honorable Mrs. Scudamore Runnymede]122-the honorable mrs. scudamore runnymede 's last novel , A Bad Un to Beat . [He]85-tom brown says [all the Smart Set]1835-all the smart set are talking of it , and it seems [the police]1836-the police have to regulate [the crowd]1837-the crowd at [Mudie 's]16-mudie 's . [You]1833-you know [I]602-the reviewer read everything [Mrs. Runnymede]122-the honorable mrs. scudamore runnymede writes , so [I]602-the reviewer set out [Miggs]126-miggs directly to beg , borrow or steal a copy , and [I]602-the reviewer confess [I]602-the reviewer burnt the midnight oil before [I]602-the reviewer laid it down . Now , mind [you]1833-you get it , [you]1833-you will find it so awfully chic . "[602-the reviewer] Nearly all the novelists on [Messrs Beit]121-messrs beit 's list were [ladies]596-ladies , [their]596-ladies works all ran to three volumes , and all of them pleased the Press , the Review , and [Miranda of Smart Society]123-miranda . One of these books , [Millicent]127-millicent 's Marriage , by [Sarah Pocklington Sanders]128-sarah pocklington sanders , was pronounced fit to lie on [the school - room]597-the school - room table , on the [drawing - room bookshelf]598-drawing - room bookshelf , or beneath the pillow of [the most gently nurtured of [[our]600-we daughters]601-our daughters]599-the most gently nurtured of our daughters . " This , "[602-the reviewer] [the reviewer]602-the reviewer went on , " is high praise , especially in these days when [we]600-we are deafened by the loud - voiced clamor of self - styled ' [artists]1838-artists . ' [We]600-we would warn [the young men who prate so persistently of style and literature , construction and prose harmonies]1839-the young men who prate so persistently of style and literature , construction and prose harmonies , that [we]600-we believe [the English reading public]1840-the english reading public will have none of [them]1839-the young men who prate so persistently of style and literature , construction and prose harmonies . Harmless amusement , a gentle flow of domestic interest , a faithful reproduction of the open and manly life of [the hunting field]1841-the hunting field , pictures of innocent and healthy English girlhood such as [Miss Sanders]129-miss sanders here affords [us]600-we ; these are the topics that will always find a welcome in [[our]600-we homes]1842-our homes , which remain bolted and barred against [the abandoned artist]1843-the abandoned artist and [the scrofulous stylist]1844-the scrofulous stylist . "[615-that modest maiden] [He]602-the reviewer turned over the pages of the little book and chuckled in high relish ; [he]602-the reviewer discovered an honest enthusiasm , a determination to strike a blow for the good and true that refreshed and exhilarated . [A beaming face , spectacled and whiskered probably , an expansive waistcoat , and a tender heart]603-a beaming face , spectacled and whiskered probably , an expansive waistcoat , and a tender heart , seemed to shine through the words which [Messrs Beit]121-messrs beit had quoted ; and the alliteration of the final sentence ; that was good too ; there was style for [you]604-you if [you]604-you wanted it . The champion of the blushing cheek and the gushing eye showed that [he]602-the reviewer too could handle the weapons of [the enemy]1823-the enemy if [he]602-the reviewer cared to trouble [himself]602-the reviewer with such things . [Lucian]73-lucian leant back and roared with indecent laughter till the tabby tom - cat who had succeeded to the poor dead beasts looked up reproachfully from [his]602-the reviewer sunny corner , with a face like [the reviewer]602-the reviewer 's , innocent and round and whiskered . At last [he]602-the reviewer turned to [his]602-the reviewer parcel and drew out some half - dozen sheets of manuscript , and began to read in a rather desponding spirit ; it was pretty obvious , [he]602-the reviewer thought , that the stuff was poor and beneath the standard of publication . The book had taken a year and a half in the making ; it was a pious attempt to translate into English prose the form and mystery of [the domed hills]607-the domed hills , the magic of [occult valleys]608-occult valleys , the sound of [the red swollen brook swirling through leafless woods]609-the red swollen brook swirling through leafless woods . Day - dreams and toil at nights had gone into the eager pages , [he]602-the reviewer had labored hard to do [his]602-the reviewer very best , writing and rewriting , weighing [his]602-the reviewer cadences , beginning over and over again , grudging no patience , no trouble if only it might be pretty good ; good enough to print and sell to [a reading public which had become critical]610-a reading public which had become critical . [He]602-the reviewer glanced through the manuscript in [his]602-the reviewer hand , and to [his]602-the reviewer astonishment , [he]602-the reviewer could not help thinking that in its measure it was decent work . After three months [his]602-the reviewer prose seemed fresh and strange as if it had been wrought by [another man]611-another man , and in spite of [himself]602-the reviewer [he]602-the reviewer found charming things , and impressions that were not commonplace . [He]602-the reviewer knew how weak it all was compared with [his]602-the reviewer own conceptions ; [he]602-the reviewer had seen [an enchanted city]612-an enchanted city , awful , glorious , with flame smitten about [its]612-an enchanted city battlements , like [the cities of [the Sangraal]17-the sangraal]613-the cities of the sangraal , and [he]602-the reviewer had molded [his]602-the reviewer copy in such poor clay as came to [his]602-the reviewer hand ; yet , in spite of the gulf that yawned between the idea and the work , [he]602-the reviewer knew as [he]602-the reviewer read that the thing accomplished was very far from a failure . [He]602-the reviewer put back the leaves carefully , and glanced again at [Messrs Beit]121-messrs beit 's list . It had escaped [his]602-the reviewer notice that A Bad Un to Beat was in its third three - volume edition . It was a great thing , at all events , to know in what direction to aim , if [he]602-the reviewer wished to succeed . If [he]602-the reviewer worked hard , [he]602-the reviewer thought , [he]602-the reviewer might some day win the approval of [the coy and retiring Miranda of [Smart Society]15-smart society]614-the coy and retiring miranda of smart society ; [that modest maiden]615-that modest maiden might in [his]602-the reviewer praise interrupt [her]615-that modest maiden task of disinterested advertisement , [her]615-that modest maiden philanthropic counsels to " go to [Jumper]130-jumper 's , and mind [you]1845-you ask for [Mr. C. "[341-his father] [He]602-the reviewer put down the pamphlet , and laughed again at the books and [the reviewers]616-the reviewers : so that [he]602-the reviewer might not weep . This then was English fiction , this was English criticism , and farce , after all , was but an ill - played tragedy . The rejected manuscript was hidden away , and [[his]602-the reviewer father]341-his father quoted [Horace]131-horace 's maxim as to the benefit of keeping literary works for some time " in the wood . "[625-the relative who had once promised assistance] There was nothing to grumble at , though [Lucian]73-lucian was inclined to think the duration of [the reader]618-the reader 's catarrh a little exaggerated . But this was a trifle ; [he]73-lucian did not arrogate to [himself]73-lucian the position of [a small commercial traveler , who expects prompt civility as a matter of course , and not at all as a favor]619-a small commercial traveler , who expects prompt civility as a matter of course , and not at all as a favor . [He]73-lucian simply forgot [his]73-lucian old book , and resolved that [he]73-lucian would make a better one if [he]73-lucian could . With the hot fit of resolution , the determination not to be snuffed out by one refusal upon [him]73-lucian , [he]73-lucian began to beat about in [his]73-lucian mind for some new scheme . At first it seemed that [he]73-lucian had hit upon a promising subject ; [he]73-lucian began to plot out chapters and scribble hints for the curious story that had entered [his]73-lucian mind , arranging [his]73-lucian circumstances and noting the effects to be produced with all the enthusiasm of [the artist]620-the artist . But after the first breath the aspect of the work changed ; page after page was tossed aside as hopeless , the beautiful sentences [he]73-lucian had dreamed of refused to be written , and [his]73-lucian puppets remained stiff and wooden , devoid of life or motion . Then all the old despairs came back , the agonies of [the artificer who strives and perseveres in vain]621-the artificer who strives and perseveres in vain ; the scheme that seemed of amorous fire turned to cold hard ice in [his]73-lucian hands . [He]73-lucian let the pen drop from [his]73-lucian fingers , and wondered how [he]73-lucian could have ever dreamed of writing books . Again , the thought occurred that [he]73-lucian might do something if [he]73-lucian could only get away , and join [the sad procession]622-the sad procession in [the murmuring [London]11-london streets]623-the murmuring london streets , far from the shadow of [those awful hills]624-those awful hills . But it was quite impossible ; [the relative who had once promised assistance]625-the relative who had once promised assistance was appealed to , and wrote expressing [his]625-the relative who had once promised assistance regret that [Lucian]73-lucian had turned out a " loafer , "[602-the reviewer] wasting [his]73-lucian time in scribbling , instead of trying to earn [his]73-lucian living . [Lucian]73-lucian felt rather hurt at this letter , but [the parson]1635-the parson only grinned grimly as usual . [He]73-lucian was thinking of how [he]73-lucian signed a check many years before , in the days of [his]73-lucian prosperity , and the check was payable to [this didactic relative]627-this didactic relative , then in but a poor way , and of a thankful turn of mind . The old rejected manuscript had almost passed out of [his]73-lucian recollection . It was recalled oddly enough . [He]73-lucian was looking over [the Reader]618-the reader , and enjoying the admirable literary criticisms , some three months after the return of [his]73-lucian book , when [his]73-lucian eye was attracted by a quoted passage in one of the notices . The thought and style both wakened memory , the cadences were familiar and beloved . [He]73-lucian read through the review from the beginning ; it was a very favorable one , and pronounced the volume an immense advance on [Mr. Ritson]132-mr. ritson 's previous work . " Here , undoubtedly , [the author]591-the author has discovered a vein of pure metal , "[602-the reviewer] [the reviewer]602-the reviewer added , " and [we]1847-we predict that [he]591-the author will go far . "[647-the man] [Lucian]73-lucian had not yet reached [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father 's stage , [he]73-lucian was unable to grin in the manner of [that irreverent parson]631-that irreverent parson . The passage selected for high praise was taken almost word for word from the manuscript now resting in [[his]73-lucian room]632-his room , the work that had not reached the high standard of [Messrs Beit & Co.]121-messrs beit , who , curiously enough , were [the publishers of the book reviewed in the Reader]633-the publishers of the book reviewed in the reader . [He]73-lucian had a few shillings in [his]73-lucian possession , and wrote at once to [a bookseller in [London]11-london]634-a bookseller in london for a copy of The Chorus in [Green]19-green , as [the author]591-the author had oddly named the book . [He]73-lucian wrote on June 21st and thought [he]73-lucian might fairly expect to receive the interesting volume by the 24th ; but [the postman]636-the postman , true to [his]636-the postman tradition , brought nothing for [him]73-lucian , and in the afternoon [he]73-lucian resolved to walk down to [Caermaen]7-caermaen , in case it might have come by a second post ; or it might have been mislaid at [the office]637-the office ; [they]638-they forgot parcels sometimes , especially when the bag was heavy and the weather hot . This 24th was a sultry and oppressive day ; a grey veil of cloud obscured the sky , and a vaporous mist hung heavily over [the land]462-the land , and fumed up from [the valleys]493-the valleys . But at five o'clock , when [he]73-lucian started , the clouds began to break , and the sunlight suddenly streamed down through the misty air , making ways and channels of rich glory , and bright islands in the gloom . It was a pleasant and shining evening when , passing by [devious back streets]641-devious back streets to avoid [the barbarians]642-the barbarians ( as [he]73-lucian very rudely called [the respectable inhabitants of [the town]387-the town]643-the respectable inhabitants of the town ) , [he]73-lucian reached [the post - office]645-the post - office ; which was also [the general shop]646-the general shop . " Yes , [Mr. Taylor]79-mr. taylor , there is something for [you]79-mr. taylor , [sir]1765-sir , "[647-the man] said [the man]647-the man . " [Williams]133-williams [the postman]636-the postman forgot to take it up this morning , "[73-lucian] and [he]647-the man handed over the packet . [Lucian]73-lucian took it under [his]73-lucian arm and went slowly through [the ragged winding lanes]648-the ragged winding lanes till [he]73-lucian came into [the country]459-the country . [He]73-lucian got over the first stile on [the road]287-the road , and sitting down in the shelter of a hedge , cut the strings and opened the parcel . The Chorus in [Green]19-green was got up in what reviewers call a dainty manner : a bronze - green cloth , well - cut gold lettering , wide margins and black " old - face "[1850-mr. ritsonâ€”that old literary hand] type , all witnessed to the good taste of [Messrs Beit & Co.]121-messrs beit [He]73-lucian cut the pages hastily and began to read . [He]73-lucian soon found that [he]73-lucian had wronged [Mr. Ritsonâ€”that old literary hand]1850-mr. ritsonâ€”that old literary hand had by no means stolen [his]73-lucian book wholesale , as [he]73-lucian had expected . There were about two hundred pages in the pretty little volume , and of these about ninety were [Lucian]73-lucian 's , dovetailed into a rather different scheme with skill that was nothing short of exquisite . And [Mr. Ritson]132-mr. ritson 's own work was often very good ; spoilt here and there for some tastes by the "[73-lucian] cataloguing " method , a somewhat materialistic way of taking an inventory of the holy country things ; but , for that very reason , contrasting to a great advantage with [Lucian]73-lucian 's hints and dreams and note of haunting . And here and there [Mr. Ritson]132-mr. ritson had made little alterations in the style of the passages [he]132-mr. ritson had conveyed , and most of these alterations were amendments , as [Lucian]73-lucian was obliged to confess , though [he]73-lucian would have liked to argue one or two points with [[his]73-lucian collaborator]1851-his collaborator and [corrector]1852-corrector . [He]73-lucian lit [his]73-lucian pipe and leant back comfortably in the hedge , thinking things over , weighing very coolly [his]73-lucian experience of humanity , [his]73-lucian contact with the "[1850-mr. ritsonâ€”that old literary hand] society " of [the countryside]563-the countryside , the affair of [the The Chorus in [Green]19-green]1854-the the chorus in green , and even some little incidents that had struck [him]73-lucian as [he]73-lucian was walking through [the streets of [Caermaen]7-caermaen]1855-the streets of caermaen that evening . At [the post - office]645-the post - office , when [he]73-lucian was inquiring for [his]73-lucian parcel , [he]73-lucian had heard [two old women]1857-two old women grumbling in [the street]1858-the street ; it seemed , so far as [he]73-lucian could make out , that [both]1859-both had been disappointed in much the same way . [One]1691-one was [a Roman Catholic]1861-a roman catholic , hardened , and beyond the reach of conversion ; [she]1691-one had been advised to ask alms of [the priests]1862-the priests , "[92-mr. dixon] who are always creeping and crawling about . " [The other old sinner]1863-the other old sinner was [a Dissenter]1864-a dissenter , and , "[92-mr. dixon] [Mr. Dixon]92-mr. dixon has quite enough to do to relieve good [Church people]651-church people .
