[He]73-lucian would look up at the soft blue of the summer sky , and at [the vast dim mountain hovering like a cloud in the west]2272-the vast dim mountain hovering like a cloud in the west , and then at the scene illumined by a flaring light , and contrasted with violent shadows . The subdued mutter of conversation in a strange language rising from bench after bench , swift hissing whispers of explanation , now and then a shout or a cry as the interest deepened , the restless tossing of [the people]654-the people as the end drew near , an arm lifted , a cloak thrown back , the sudden blaze of a torch lighting up purple or white or the gleam of gold in the black serried ranks ; these were impressions that seemed always amazing . And above , the dusky light of the stars , around , the sweet - scented meadows , and the twinkle of lamps from [the still city]2274-the still city , the cry of [the sentries about the walls]2275-the sentries about the walls , the wash of the tide filling [the river]1634-the river , and the salt savor of [the sea]1719-the sea . With such a scenic ornament [he]73-lucian saw the tale of [Apuleius]207-apuleius represented , heard the names of [Fotis]208-fotis and [Byrrhaena]209-byrrhaena and [Lucius]73-lucian proclaimed , and the deep intonation of such sentences as Ecce Veneris hortator et armiger Liber advenit ultro . The tale went on through all its marvelous adventures , and [Lucian]73-lucian left [the amphitheatre]1952-the amphitheatre and walked beside [the river]1634-the river where [he]73-lucian could hear indistinctly the noise of voices and the singing Latin , and note how the rumor of [the stage]2280-the stage mingled with the murmur of the shuddering reeds and the cool lapping of the tide . Then came the farewell of [the cantor]2281-the cantor , the thunder of applause , the crash of cymbals , the calling of the flutes , and the surge of the wind in the great dark wood . At other times it was [his]73-lucian chief pleasure to spend a whole day in [a vineyard planted on the steep slope beyond [the bridge]2283-the bridge]2282-a vineyard planted on the steep slope beyond the bridge . A grey stone seat had been placed beneath a shady laurel , and [here]492-here [he]73-lucian often sat without motion or gesture for many hours . Below [him]73-lucian [the tawny river]2285-the tawny river swept round [the town]387-the town in a half circle ; [he]73-lucian could see the swirl of the yellow water , its eddies and miniature whirlpools , as the tide poured up from the south . And beyond [the river]1634-the river the strong circuit of the walls , and within , [the city]1961-the city glittered like a charming piece of mosaic . [He]73-lucian freed [himself]73-lucian from the obtuse modern view of [towns]2289-towns as places where [human beings]1030-human beings live and make money and rejoice or suffer , for from the standpoint of the moment such facts were wholly impertinent . [He]73-lucian knew perfectly well that for [his]73-lucian present purpose the tawny sheen and shimmer of the tide was the only fact of importance about [the river]1634-the river , and so [he]73-lucian regarded [the city]1961-the city as a curious work in jewelry . [Its]1961-the city radiant marble porticoes , the white walls of [the villas]2293-the villas , a dome of burning copper , the flash and scintillation of [tiled roofs]2294-tiled roofs , the quiet red of brickwork , dark groves of ilex , and cypress , and laurel , glowing [rose - gardens]2295-rose - gardens , and here and there the silver of a fountain , seemed arranged and contrasted with a wonderful art , and [the town]387-the town appeared a delicious ornament , every cube of color owing its place to the thought and inspiration of [the artificer]2297-the artificer . [Lucian]73-lucian , as [he]73-lucian gazed from [his]73-lucian arbour amongst the trellised vines , lost none of the subtle pleasures of the sight ; noting every nuance of color , [he]73-lucian let [his]73-lucian eyes dwell for a moment on the scarlet flash of poppies , and then on a glazed roof which in the glance of the sun seemed to spout white fire . A square of vines was like some rare green stone ; the grapes were massed so richly amongst the vivid leaves , that even from far off there was a sense of irregular flecks and stains of purple running through the green . The laurel garths were like cool jade ; [the gardens]1101-the gardens , where red , yellow , blue and white gleamed together in a mist of heat , had the radiance of opal ; [the river]1634-the river was a band of dull gold . On every side , as if to enhance the preciousness of [the city]1961-the city , [the woods]331-the woods hung dark on [the hills]1660-the hills ; above , the sky was violet , specked with minute feathery clouds , white as snowflakes . It reminded [him]73-lucian of a beautiful bowl in [[his]73-lucian villa]1127-his villa ; the ground was of that same brilliant blue , and [the artist]620-the artist had fused into the work , when it was hot , particles of pure white glass . For [Lucian]73-lucian this was a spectacle that enchanted many hours ; leaning on one hand , [he]73-lucian would gaze at [the city]1961-the city glowing in the sunlight till the purple shadows grew down [the slopes]2306-the slopes and the long melodious trumpet sounded for the evening watch . Then , as [he]73-lucian strolled beneath the trellises , [he]73-lucian would see all the radiant facets glimmering out , and [the city]1961-the city faded into haze , a white wall shining here and there , and [the gardens]1101-the gardens veiled in a dim glow of color . On such an evening [he]73-lucian would go [home]308-home with the sense that [he]73-lucian had truly lived a day , having received for many hours the most acute impressions of beautiful color . Often [he]73-lucian spent the night in [the cool court of [[his]73-lucian villa]1127-his villa]2310-the cool court of his villa , lying amidst soft cushions heaped upon the marble bench . A lamp stood on the table at [his]73-lucian elbow , its light making the water in the cistern twinkle . There was no sound in [the court]2312-the court except the soft continual plashing of the fountain . Throughout these still hours [he]73-lucian would meditate , and [he]73-lucian became more than ever convinced that [man]2313-man could , if [he]2313-man pleased , become lord of [his]2313-man own sensations . This , surely , was the true meaning concealed under the beautiful symbolism of alchemy . Some years before [he]73-lucian had read many of the wonderful alchemical books of the later Middle Ages , and had suspected that something other than the turning of lead into gold was intended . This impression was deepened when [he]73-lucian looked into [Lumen de Lumine]210-lumen de lumine by [Vaughan]120-mr. vaughan , [the brother of [the Silurist]2315-the silurist]2314-the brother of the silurist , and [he]73-lucian had long puzzled [himself]73-lucian in the endeavor to find a reasonable interpretation of the hermetic mystery , and of the red powder , "[204-ben - hur] glistening and glorious in the sun . " And the solution shone out at last , bright and amazing , as [he]73-lucian lay quiet in [the court of [Avallaunius]31-avallaunius]2316-the court of avallaunius . [He]73-lucian knew that [he]73-lucian [himself]73-lucian had solved the riddle , that [he]73-lucian held in [his]73-lucian hand the powder of projection , [the philosopher]2317-the philosopher 's stone transmuting all it touched to fine gold ; the gold of exquisite impressions . [He]73-lucian understood now something of the alchemical symbolism ; the crucible and the furnace , the "[204-ben - hur] Green Dragon , " and the "[31-avallaunius] Son Blessed of the Fire " had , [he]73-lucian saw , a peculiar meaning . [He]73-lucian understood , too , why [the uninitiated]2318-the uninitiated were warned of the terror and danger through which [they]2318-the uninitiated must pass ; and the vehemence with which [the adepts]2319-the adepts disclaimed all desire for material riches no longer struck [him]73-lucian as singular . [The wise man]1037-the wise man does not endure the torture of the furnace in order that [he]1037-the wise man may be able to compete with [operators]2321-operators in pork and [company promoters]2322-company promoters ; neither [a steam yacht]2323-a steam yacht , nor [a grouse - moor]2324-a grouse - moor , nor [three liveried footmen]2325-three liveried footmen would add at all to [his]1037-the wise man gratifications . Again [Lucian]73-lucian said to [himself]73-lucian : "[31-avallaunius] Only in [the court of [Avallaunius]31-avallaunius]2316-the court of avallaunius is the true science of the exquisite to be found . " [He]73-lucian saw the true gold into which the beggarly matter of existence may be transmuted by spagyric art ; a succession of delicious moments , all the rare flavors of life concentrated , purged of [their]2318-the uninitiated lees , and preserved in a beautiful vessel . The moonlight fell green on the fountain and on the curious pavements , and in the long sweet silence of the night [he]73-lucian lay still and felt that thought itself was an acute pleasure , to be expressed perhaps in terms of odor or color by [the true artist]2326-the true artist . And [he]73-lucian gave [himself]73-lucian other and even stranger gratifications . Outside the city walls , between [the baths]2327-the baths and [the amphitheatre]1952-the amphitheatre , was [a tavern]2329-a tavern , [a place where [wonderful people]2331-wonderful people met to drink wonderful wine]2330-a place where wonderful people met to drink wonderful wine . There [he]73-lucian saw [priests of Mithras and Isis and of more occult rites]2332-priests of mithras and isis and of more occult rites from [the East]34-the east , [men who wore robes of bright colours , and grotesque ornaments , symbolizing secret things]2333-men who wore robes of bright colours , and grotesque ornaments , symbolizing secret things . [They]2333-men who wore robes of bright colours , and grotesque ornaments , symbolizing secret things spoke amongst [themselves]2333-men who wore robes of bright colours , and grotesque ornaments , symbolizing secret things in a rich jargon of colored words , full of hidden meanings and the sense of matters unintelligible to [the uninitiated]2318-the uninitiated , alluding to what was concealed beneath roses , and calling [each other by strange names]2335-each other by strange names . And there were [actors who gave the shows in [the amphitheatre]1952-the amphitheatre]2336-actors who gave the shows in the amphitheatre , [officers of the legion who had served in wild places]2338-officers of the legion who had served in wild places , [singers]2339-singers , and [dancing girls]2340-dancing girls , and [heroes of strange adventure]2341-heroes of strange adventure . The walls of [the tavern]2342-the tavern were covered with pictures painted in violent hues ; blues and reds and greens jarring against one another and lighting up the gloom of [the place]2343-the place . The stone benches were always crowded , the sunlight came in through the door in a long bright beam , casting a dancing shadow of vine leaves on the further wall . There [a painter]2344-a painter had made a joyous figure of [the young Bacchus]2345-the young bacchus driving the leopards before [him]2345-the young bacchus with [his]2345-the young bacchus ivy - staff , and the quivering shadow seemed a part of the picture . [The room]2083-the room was cool and dark and cavernous , but the scent and heat of the summer gushed in through the open door . There was ever a full sound , with noise and vehemence , there , and the rolling music of the Latin tongue never ceased . "[31-avallaunius] The wine of the siege , the wine that [we]1138-we saved , " cried [one]1691-one . "[31-avallaunius] Look for the jar marked [Faunus]212-faunus ; [you]1139-you will be glad . " "[1140-the owl] Bring [me]0-i the wine of [the Owl]1140-the owl 's Face . " "[213-saturn] Let [us]1138-we have the wine of [[Saturn]213-saturn 's Bridge]1141-saturn 's bridge . " [The boys who served brought the wine in dull red jars that struck a charming note against [their]2348-the boys who served brought the wine in dull red jars that struck a charming note against their white robes white robes]2348-the boys who served brought the wine in dull red jars that struck a charming note against their white robes . [They]2348-the boys who served brought the wine in dull red jars that struck a charming note against their white robes poured out the violet and purple and golden wine with calm sweet faces as if [they]2348-the boys who served brought the wine in dull red jars that struck a charming note against their white robes were assisting in the mysteries , without any sign that [they]2348-the boys who served brought the wine in dull red jars that struck a charming note against their white robes heard the strange words that flashed from side to side . The cups were all of glass ; some were of deep green , of the color of [the sea]1719-the sea near [the land]462-the land , flawed and specked with the bubbles of the furnace . Others were of brilliant scarlet , streaked with irregular bands of white , and having the appearance of white globules in the molded stem . There were cups of dark glowing blue , deeper and more shining than the blue of the sky , and running through the substance of the glass were veins of rich gamboge yellow , twining from the brim to the foot . Some cups were of a troubled and clotted red , with alternating blotches of dark and light , some were variegated with white and yellow stains , some wore a film of rainbow colours , some glittered , shot with gold threads through the clear crystal , some were as if sapphires hung suspended in running water , some sparkled with the glint of stars , some were black and golden like tortoiseshell . A strange feature was the constant and fluttering motion of hands and arms . Gesture made a constant commentary on speech ; white fingers , whiter arms , and sleeves of all colours , hovered restlessly , appeared and disappeared with an effect of threads crossing and re - crossing on the loom . And the odor of [the place]2343-the place was both curious and memorable ; something of the damp cold breath of [the cave]2352-the cave meeting the hot blast of summer , the strangely mingled aromas of rare wines as [they]2353-they fell plashing and ringing into the cups , the drugged vapor of the East that [the priests of [Mithras]196-mithras]2354-the priests of mithras and [Isis]214-isis bore from [[their]2354-the priests of mithras steaming temples]2355-their steaming temples ; these were always strong and dominant . And [the women]754-the women were scented , sometimes with unctuous and overpowering perfumes , and to [the artist]620-the artist the experiences of [those present]2358-those present were hinted in subtle and delicate nuances of odor . [They]754-the women drank [their]754-the women wine and caressed all day in [the tavern]2342-the tavern . [The women]754-the women threw [their]754-the women round white arms about [[their]754-the women lover]2361-their lover 's necks , [they]754-the women intoxicated [them]2361-their lover with the scent of [their]754-the women hair , [the priests]1862-the priests muttered [their]1862-the priests fantastic jargon of Theurgy . And through the sonorous clash of voices there always seemed the ring of the cry : "[213-saturn] Look for the jar marked [Faunus]212-faunus ; [you]1142-you will be glad . " Outside , the vine tendrils shook on the white walls glaring in the sunshine ; the breeze swept up from [the yellow river]2363-the yellow river , pungent with the salt sea savor . [These tavern]2364-these tavern scenes were often the subject of [Lucian]73-lucian 's meditation as [he]73-lucian sat amongst the cushions on the marble seat . The rich sound of the voices impressed [him]73-lucian above all things , and [he]73-lucian saw that words have a far higher reason than the utilitarian office of imparting [a man]687-a man 's thought . The common notion that language and linked words are important only as a means of expression [he]73-lucian found a little ridiculous ; as if electricity were to be studied solely with the view of "[213-saturn] wiring " to [people]478-people , and all its other properties left unexplored , neglected . Language , [he]73-lucian understood , was chiefly important for the beauty of its sounds , by its possession of words resonant , glorious to the ear , by its capacity , when exquisitely arranged , of suggesting wonderful and indefinable impressions , perhaps more ravishing and farther removed from the domain of strict thought than the impressions excited by music itself . Here lay hidden the secret of the sensuous art of literature ; it was the secret of suggestion , the art of causing delicious sensation by the use of words . In a way , therefore , literature was independent of thought ; [the mere English listener]2367-the mere english listener , if [he]2367-the mere english listener had an ear attuned , could recognize the beauty of a splendid Latin phrase . Here was the explanation of the magic of [Lycidas]215-lycidas . From the standpoint of the formal understanding it was an affected lament over some wholly uninteresting and unimportant [Mr. King]216-mr. king ; it was full of nonsense about "[213-saturn] [shepherds]1143-shepherds " and "[1144-muses] flocks " and "[213-saturn] [muses]1144-muses " and such stale stock of poetry ; the introduction of [St Peter]217-st peter on a stage thronged with [nymphs and river gods]2368-nymphs and river gods was blasphemous , absurd , and , in the worst taste ; there were touches of greasy Puritanism , the twang of the conventicle was only too apparent . And [Lycidas]215-lycidas was probably the most perfect piece of pure literature in existence ; because every word and phrase and line were sonorous , ringing and echoing with music . "[1144-muses] Literature , " [he]73-lucian re - enunciated in [his]73-lucian mind , "[1144-muses] is the sensuous art of causing exquisite impressions by means of words . " And yet there was something more ; besides the logical thought , which was often a hindrance , a troublesome though inseparable accident , besides the sensation , always a pleasure and a delight , besides these there were the indefinable inexpressible images which all fine literature summons to the mind . As [the chemist]2369-the chemist in [his]73-lucian experiments is sometimes astonished to find unknown , unexpected elements in the crucible or the receiver , as the world of material things is considered by some a thin veil of the immaterial universe , so [he]73-lucian who reads wonderful prose or verse is conscious of suggestions that can not be put into words , which do not rise from the logical sense , which are rather parallel to than connected with the sensuous delight . The world so disclosed is rather the world of dreams , rather the world in which [children sometimes live , instantly appearing , and instantly vanishing away]2370-children sometimes live , instantly appearing , and instantly vanishing away , a world beyond all expression or analysis , neither of the intellect nor of the senses . [He]73-lucian called these fancies of [his]73-lucian "[1144-muses] Meditations of [a Tavern]2329-a tavern , " and was amused to think that a theory of letters should have risen from the eloquent noise that rang all day about the violet and golden wine . "[1144-muses] Let [us]1146-us seek for more exquisite things , " said [Lucian]73-lucian to [himself]73-lucian . [He]73-lucian could almost imagine the magic transmutation of the senses accomplished , the strong sunlight was an odor in [his]73-lucian nostrils ; it poured down on the white marble and the palpitating roses like a flood . The sky was a glorious blue , making the heart joyous , and the eyes could rest in the dark green leaves and purple shadow of the ilex . [The earth]333-the earth seemed to burn and leap beneath the sun , [he]73-lucian fancied [he]73-lucian could see the vine tendrils stir and quiver in the heat , and the faint fume of the scorching pine needles was blown across [the gleaming garden]2372-the gleaming garden to the seat beneath [the porch]2373-the porch . Wine was before [him]73-lucian in a cup of carved amber ; a wine of the color of a dark rose , with a glint as of a star or of a jet of flame deep beneath the brim ; and the cup was twined about with a delicate wreath of ivy . [He]73-lucian was often loath to turn away from the still contemplation of such things , from the mere joy of the violent sun , and [the responsive earth]2374-the responsive earth . [He]73-lucian loved [[his]73-lucian garden]2375-his garden and the view of [the tessellated city]2376-the tessellated city from [the vineyard on [the hill]268-the hill]2377-the vineyard on the hill , the strange clamor of [the tavern]2342-the tavern , and white Fotis appearing on the torch - lit stage . And there were shops in [the town]387-the town in which [he]73-lucian delighted , [the shops of [the perfume makers]2382-the perfume makers]2381-the shops of the perfume makers , and [jewelers]2383-jewelers , and [dealers in curious ware]2384-dealers in curious ware . [He]73-lucian loved to see all things made for [ladies]596-ladies ' use , to touch the gossamer silks that were to touch [their]596-ladies bodies , to finger the beads of amber and the gold chains which would stir above [their]596-ladies hearts , to handle the carved hairpins and brooches , to smell odors which were already dedicated to love . But though these were sweet and delicious gratifications , [he]73-lucian knew that there were more exquisite things of which [he]73-lucian might be [a spectator]2386-a spectator . [He]73-lucian had seen the folly of regarding fine literature from the standpoint of the logical intellect , and [he]73-lucian now began to question the wisdom of looking at life as if it were a moral representation . Literature , [he]73-lucian knew , could not exist without some meaning , and considerations of right and wrong were to a certain extent inseparable from the conception of life , but to insist on ethics as the chief interest of the human pageant was surely absurd . [One]1691-one might as well read Lycidas for the sake of its denunciation of "[1144-muses] [[our]1147-our corrupted Clergy]1148-our corrupted clergy , " or [Homer]218-homer for "[1144-muses] manners and customs . " [An artist entranced by [a beautiful landscape]2389-a beautiful landscape]2388-an artist entranced by a beautiful landscape did not greatly concern [himself]2388-an artist entranced by a beautiful landscape with the geological formation of [the hills]1660-the hills , nor did [the lover of [a wild sea]2392-a wild sea]2391-the lover of a wild sea inquire as to the chemical analysis of [the water]2393-the water . [Lucian]73-lucian saw a colored and complex life displayed before [him]73-lucian , and [he]73-lucian sat enraptured at the spectacle , not concerned to know whether actions were good or bad , but content if [they]2394-they were curious . In this spirit [he]73-lucian made a singular study of corruption . Beneath [his]73-lucian feet , as [he]73-lucian sat in [the garden porch]2395-the garden porch , was a block of marble through which there ran a scarlet stain . It began with a faint line , thin as a hair , and grew as it advanced , sending out offshoots to right and left , and broadening to a pool of brilliant red . There were strange lives into which [he]73-lucian looked that were like the block of marble ; [women with grave sweet faces]2396-women with grave sweet faces told [him]73-lucian the astounding tale of [their]2396-women with grave sweet faces adventures , and how , [they]2396-women with grave sweet faces said , [they]2396-women with grave sweet faces had met [the faun]2397-the faun when [they]2396-women with grave sweet faces were [little children]2398-little children . [They]2396-women with grave sweet faces told [him]73-lucian how [they]2396-women with grave sweet faces had played and watched by the vines and the fountains , and dallied with [the nymphs]2399-the nymphs , and gazed at images reflected in [the water pools]2400-the water pools , till the authentic face appeared from the wood . [He]73-lucian heard [others]2074-others tell how [they]2074-others had loved [the satyrs]2402-the satyrs for many years before [they]2074-others knew [their]2074-others race ; and there were strange stories of [those who had longed to speak but knew not the word of the enigma]2403-those who had longed to speak but knew not the word of the enigma , and searched in all strange paths and ways before [they]2403-those who had longed to speak but knew not the word of the enigma found it . [He]73-lucian heard the history of [the woman who fell in love with [[her]2404-the woman who fell in love with her slave - boy slave - boy]2405-her slave - boy]2404-the woman who fell in love with her slave - boy , and tempted [him]73-lucian for three years in vain . [He]73-lucian heard the tale from [the woman]2029-the woman 's full red lips , and watched [her]2029-the woman face , full of the ineffable sadness of lust , as [she]2029-the woman described [her]2029-the woman curious stratagems in mellow phrases . [She]2029-the woman was drinking a sweet yellow wine from a gold cup as [she]2029-the woman spoke , and the odor in [her]2029-the woman hair and the aroma of the precious wine seemed to mingle with the soft strange words that flowed like an unguent from a carven jar . [She]2029-the woman told how [she]2029-the woman bought [the boy]1780-the boy in [the market of [an Asian city]2409-an asian city]2408-the market of an asian city , and had [him]1780-the boy carried to [[her]2029-the woman house]2410-her house in [the grove of fig - trees]2411-the grove of fig - trees . "[1149-he] Then , " [she]2029-the woman went on , "[1780-the boy] [he]1149-he was led into [my]0-i presence as [I]0-i sat between the columns of [[my]0-i court]1150-my court . A blue veil was spread above to shut out the heat of the sun , and rather twilight than light shone on the painted walls , and the wonderful colours of [the pavement]2235-the pavement , and the images of Love and [the Mother of Love]1152-the mother of love . [The men who brought [the boy]1780-the boy]1153-the men who brought the boy gave [him]1780-the boy over to [[my]0-i girls]1155-my girls , who undressed [him]1780-the boy before [me]0-i , one drawing gently away [his]1780-the boy robe , another stroking [his]1780-the boy brown and flowing hair , another praising the whiteness of [his]1780-the boy limbs , and another caressing [him]1780-the boy , and speaking loving words in [his]1780-the boy hear . But [the boy]1780-the boy looked sullenly at [them]1155-my girls all , striking away [their]1155-my girls hands , and pouting with [his]1780-the boy lovely and splendid lips , and [I]0-i saw a blush , like the rosy veil of dawn , reddening [his]1780-the boy body and [his]1780-the boy cheeks . Then [I]0-i made [them]1155-my girls bathe [him]1780-the boy , and anoint [him]1780-the boy with scented oils from head to foot , till [his]1780-the boy limbs shone and glistened with the gentle and mellow glow of an ivory statue . Then [I]0-i said : ' [You]1780-the boy are bashful , because [you]1780-the boy shine alone amongst [us]1157-us all ; see , [we]1157-us too will be [[your]1780-the boy fellows]1158-your fellows . ' [The girls]1869-the girls began first of all , fondling and kissing [one another]2011-one another , and doing for each other the offices of [waiting - maids]1161-waiting - maids . [They]1155-my girls drew out the pins and loosened the bands of [their]1155-my girls hair , and [I]0-i never knew before that [they]1155-my girls were so lovely . The soft and shining tresses flowed down , rippling like sea - waves ; [some]1162-some had hair golden and radiant as this wine in [my]0-i cup , the faces of others appeared amidst the blackness of ebony ; there were locks that seemed of burnished and scintillating copper , some glowed with hair of tawny splendor , and others were crowned with the brightness of the sardonyx . Then , laughing , and without the appearance of shame , [they]1155-my girls unfastened the brooches and bands which sustained [their]1155-my girls robes , and so allowed silk and linen to flow swiftly to the stained floor , so that [one]1691-one would have said there was a sudden apparition of [the fairest nymphs]1164-the fairest nymphs . With many festive and jocose words [they]1155-my girls began to incite [each other]1165-each other to mirth , praising the beauties that shone on every side , and calling [the boy]1780-the boy by [a girl]2072-a girl 's name , [they]1155-my girls invited [him]1780-the boy to be [[their]1155-my girls playmate]1168-their playmate . But [he]1780-the boy refused , shaking [his]1780-the boy head , and still standing dumb - founded and abashed , as if [he]1780-the boy saw a forbidden and terrible spectacle . Then [I]0-i ordered [the women]754-the women to undo [my]0-i hair and [my]0-i clothes , making [them]754-the women caress [me]0-i with the tenderness of [the fondest lover]1170-the fondest lover , but without avail , for [the foolish boy]1171-the foolish boy still scowled and pouted out [his]1780-the boy lips , stained with an imperial and glorious scarlet . " [She]754-the women poured out more of the topaz - colored wine in [her]754-the women cup , and [Lucian]73-lucian saw it glitter as it rose to the brim and mirrored the gleam of the lamps . The tale went on , recounting a hundred strange devices . [The woman]2029-the woman told how [she]2029-the woman had tempted [the boy]1780-the boy by idleness and ease , giving [him]1780-the boy long hours of sleep , and allowing [him]1780-the boy to recline all day on soft cushions , that swelled about [him]1780-the boy , enclosing [his]1780-the boy body . [She]2029-the woman tried the experiment of curious odors : causing [him]1780-the boy to smell always about [him]1780-the boy the oil of roses , and burning in [his]1780-the boy presence rare gums from [the East]34-the east . [He]1780-the boy was allured by soft dresses , being clothed in silks that caressed the skin with the sense of a fondling touch . Three times a day [they]2029-the woman spread before [him]1780-the boy a delicious banquet , full of savor and odor and color ; three times a day [they]2029-the woman endeavored to intoxicate [him]1780-the boy with delicate wine . "[1780-the boy] And so , " [the lady]880-the lady continued , "[1172-him] [I]0-i spared nothing to catch [him]1172-him in the glistening nets of love ; taking only sour and contemptuous glances in return . And at last in an incredible shape [I]0-i won the victory , and then , having gained a green crown , fighting in agony against [his]1172-him green and crude immaturity , [I]0-i devoted [him]1172-him to [the theatre]1173-the theatre , where [he]1172-him amused [the people]654-the people by the splendor of [his]1172-him death . " On another evening [he]1780-the boy heard the history of [the man who dwelt alone , refusing all allurements , and was at last discovered to be the lover of a black statue]2415-the man who dwelt alone , refusing all allurements , and was at last discovered to be the lover of a black statue . And there were tales of strange cruelties , of [men]1715-men taken by [mountain robbers]2417-mountain robbers , and curiously maimed and disfigured , so that when [they]2029-the woman escaped and returned to [the town]387-the town , [they]2029-the woman were thought to be monsters and killed at [their]2029-the woman own doors . [Lucian]73-lucian left [no dark or secret nook of life unvisited]2419-no dark or secret nook of life unvisited ; [he]73-lucian sat down , as [he]73-lucian said , at the banquet , resolved to taste all the savors , and to leave no flagon unvisited . [[His]73-lucian relations]916-his relations grew seriously alarmed about [him]73-lucian at this period . While [he]1780-the boy heard with some inner ear the suave and eloquent phrases of singular tales , and watched the lamp - light in amber and purple wine , [[his]1780-the boy father]341-his father saw [a lean pale boy , with black eyes that burnt in hollows , and sad and sunken cheeks]2422-a lean pale boy , with black eyes that burnt in hollows , and sad and sunken cheeks . "[73-lucian] [You]1175-you ought to try and eat more , [Lucian]73-lucian , " said [the parson]1635-the parson ; "[1175-you] and why do n't [you]1175-you have some beer ? " [He]73-lucian was looking feebly at the roast mutton and sipping a little water ; but [he]73-lucian would not have eaten or drunk with more relish if the choicest meat and drink had been before [him]73-lucian . [His]73-lucian bones seemed , as [Miss Deacon]90-miss deacon said , to be growing through [his]73-lucian skin ; [he]73-lucian had all the appearance of [an ascetic whose body has been reduced to misery by long and grievous penance]2424-an ascetic whose body has been reduced to misery by long and grievous penance . [People who chanced to see [him]73-lucian]2425-people who chanced to see him could not help saying to [one another]2011-one another : "[73-lucian] How ill and wretched that [Lucian Taylor]73-lucian looks ! " [They]2425-people who chanced to see him were of course quite unaware of the joy and luxury in which [his]73-lucian real life was spent , and [some of [them]2425-people who chanced to see him]2427-some of them began to pity [him]73-lucian , and to speak to [him]73-lucian kindly . It was too late for that . The friendly words had as much lost their meaning as the words of contempt . [Edward Dixon]96-edward dixon hailed [him]73-lucian cheerfully in [the street]1858-the street one day : "[0-i] Come in to [[my]0-i den]1176-my den , wo n't [you]0-i , [old fellow]700-old fellow ? " [he]0-i said . "[1178-the pater] [You]0-i wo n't see [the pater]1178-the pater . [I]0-i 've managed to bag a bottle of [his]1178-the pater old port . [I]0-i know [you]0-i smoke like a furnace , and [I]0-i 've got some ripping cigars . [You]0-i will come , wo n't [you]0-i ! [I]0-i can tell [you]0-i [the pater]1178-the pater 's booze is first rate . " [He]73-lucian gently declined and went on . Kindness and unkindness , pity and contempt had become for [him]73-lucian mere phrases ; [he]73-lucian could not have distinguished one from the other . Hebrew and Chinese , [Hungarian]219-hungarian and [Pushtu]220-pushtu would be pretty much alike to [an agricultural laborer]2429-an agricultural laborer ; if [he]73-lucian cared to listen [he]73-lucian might detect some general differences in sound , but all four tongues would be equally devoid of significance . To [Lucian]73-lucian , entranced in [the garden of [Avallaunius]31-avallaunius]1124-the garden of avallaunius , it seemed very strange that [he]73-lucian had once been so ignorant of all the exquisite meanings of life . Now , beneath the violet sky , looking through the brilliant trellis of the vines , [he]73-lucian saw the picture ; before , [he]73-lucian had gazed in sad astonishment at the squalid rag which was wrapped about it . And [he]73-lucian was at last in [the city]1961-the city of [the unending murmuring streets]2432-the unending murmuring streets , a part of the stirring shadow , of the amber - lighted gloom . It seemed a long time since [he]73-lucian had knelt before [[his]73-lucian sweetheart]2035-his sweetheart in [the lane]278-the lane , the moon - fire streaming upon [them]2035-his sweetheart from the dark circle of [the fort]1672-the fort , the air and the light and [his]73-lucian soul full of haunting , the touch of the unimaginable thrilling [his]73-lucian heart ; and now [he]73-lucian sat in [a terrible "[153-mr. gervase] bed - sitting - room " in [a western suburb]2437-a western suburb]2436-a terrible " bed - sitting - room " in a western suburb , confronted by a heap and litter of papers on the desk of [a battered old bureau]2438-a battered old bureau . [He]73-lucian had put [his]73-lucian breakfast - tray out on the landing , and was thinking of the morning 's work , and of some very dubious pages that [he]73-lucian had blackened the night before . But when [he]73-lucian had lit [his]73-lucian disreputable briar , [he]73-lucian remembered there was an unopened letter waiting for [him]73-lucian on the table ; [he]73-lucian had recognized the vague , staggering script of [Miss Deacon]90-miss deacon , [[his]73-lucian cousin]1735-his cousin . There was not much news ; [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father was "[153-mr. gervase] just the same as usual , " there had been a good deal of rain , [the farmers]1677-the farmers expected to make a lot of cider , and so forth . But at the close of the letter [Miss Deacon]90-miss deacon became useful for reproof and admonition . "[0-i] [I]0-i was at [Caermaen]7-caermaen on Tuesday , " [she]90-miss deacon said , "[73-lucian] and called on [the Gervases]103-the gervases and [the Dixons]98-the dixons . [Mr. Gervase]153-mr. gervase smiled when [I]0-i told [him]153-mr. gervase [you]0-i were [a literary man]1180-a literary man , living in [London]11-london , and said [he]153-mr. gervase was afraid [you]0-i would n't find it a very practical career . [Mrs. Gervase]158-mrs. gervase was very proud of [Henry]221-henry 's success ; [he]221-henry passed fifth for some examination , and will begin with nearly four hundred a year . [I]0-i do n't wonder [the Gervases]103-the gervases are delighted . Then [I]0-i went to [the Dixons]1181-the dixons , and had tea . [Mrs. Dixon]91-mrs. dixon wanted to know if [you]0-i had published anything yet , and [I]0-i said [I]0-i thought not . [She]91-mrs. dixon showed [me]0-i a book [everybody]423-everybody is talking about , called [the Dog]1183-the dog and [the Doctor]550-the doctor . [She]91-mrs. dixon says it 's selling by [thousands]1185-thousands , and that one ca n't take up a paper without seeing [the author]591-the author 's name . [She]91-mrs. dixon told [me]0-i to tell [you]0-i that [you]0-i ought to try to write something like it . Then [Mr. Dixon]92-mr. dixon came in from [the study]1187-the study , and [your]0-i name was mentioned again . [He]92-mr. dixon said [he]92-mr. dixon was afraid [you]0-i had made rather a mistake in trying to take up literature as if it were a profession , and seemed to think that a place in [a house of business]1188-a house of business would be more suitable and more practical . [He]92-mr. dixon pointed out that [you]0-i had not had the advantages of a university training , and said that [you]0-i would find [men who had made good friends , and had the tone of the university]1189-men who had made good friends , and had the tone of the university , would be before [you]0-i at every step . [He]92-mr. dixon said [Edward]96-edward dixon was doing very well at [Oxford]14-oxford . [He]92-mr. dixon writes to [them]1190-them that [he]92-mr. dixon knows [several noblemen]1191-several noblemen , and that [young Philip Bullingham]222-young philip bullingham ( [son of [Sir John Bullingham]191-john]1192-son of sir john bullingham ) is [[his]92-mr. dixon most intimate friend]1193-his most intimate friend ; of course this is very satisfactory for [the Dixons]98-the dixons . [I]0-i am afraid , [[my]0-i dear]671-my dear [Lucian]73-lucian , [you]73-lucian have rather overrated [your]73-lucian powers . Would n't it be better , even now , to look out for some real work to do , instead of wasting [your]73-lucian time over those silly old books ? [I]0-i know quite well how [the Gervases]103-the gervases and [the Dixons]98-the dixons feel ; [they]1190-them think idleness so injurious for [a young man]1897-a young man , and likely to lead to bad habits . [You]73-lucian know , [[my]0-i dear]671-my dear [Lucian]73-lucian , [I]0-i am only writing like this because of [my]0-i affection for [you]73-lucian , so [I]0-i am sure , [[my]0-i dear boy]2147-my dear boy , [you]73-lucian wo n't be offended . " [Lucian]73-lucian pigeon - holed the letter solemnly in the receptacle lettered "[73-lucian] Barbarians . " [He]73-lucian felt that [he]73-lucian ought to ask [himself]73-lucian some serious questions : "[1148-our corrupted clergy] Why have n't [I]0-i passed fifth ? why is n't [Philip]222-young philip bullingham ( son of [Sir John]191-john ) [[my]0-i most intimate friend]1198-my most intimate friend ? why am [I]0-i [an idler]1199-an idler , liable to fall into bad habits ? " but [he]73-lucian was eager to get to [his]73-lucian work , a curious and intricate piece of analysis . So the battered bureau , the litter of papers , and the thick fume of [his]73-lucian pipe , engulfed [him]73-lucian and absorbed [him]73-lucian for the rest of the morning . Outside were the dim October mists , the dreary and languid life of [a side street]2442-a side street , and beyond , on [the main road]273-the main road , the hum and jangle of [the gliding trains]2444-the gliding trains . But [he]73-lucian heard none of the uneasy noises of [the quarter]2445-the quarter , not even the shriek of the garden gates nor the yelp of the butcher on [his]73-lucian round , for delight in [his]73-lucian great task made [him]73-lucian unconscious of [the world]286-the world outside . [He]73-lucian had come by [curious paths]2447-curious paths to [this calm hermitage]2448-this calm hermitage between [Shepherd 's Bush and [Acton Vale]35-acton vale]2449-shepherd 's bush and acton vale . The golden weeks of the summer passed on in [their]2450-their enchanted procession , and [Annie]75-annie had not returned , neither had [she]75-annie written . [Lucian]73-lucian , on [his]73-lucian side , sat apart , wondering why [his]73-lucian longing for [her]75-annie were not sharper . As [he]73-lucian though of [his]73-lucian raptures [he]73-lucian would smile faintly to [himself]73-lucian , and wonder whether [he]73-lucian had not lost [the world]286-the world and [Annie]75-annie with it . In [the garden of [Avallaunius]31-avallaunius]1124-the garden of avallaunius [his]73-lucian sense of external things had grown dim and indistinct ; the actual , material life seemed every day to become a show , a fleeting of shadows across a great white light . At last the news came that [Annie Morgan]75-annie had been married from [[[her]75-annie sister]2453-her sister 's house]2454-her sister 's house to [a young farmer , to whom it appeared , [she]75-annie had been long engaged]2455-a young farmer , to whom it appeared , she had been long engaged , and [Lucian]73-lucian was ashamed to find [himself]73-lucian only conscious of amusement , mingled with gratitude . [She]75-annie had been the key that opened [the shut palace]2456-the shut palace , and [he]73-lucian was now secure on the throne of ivory and gold . A few days after [he]73-lucian had heard the news [he]73-lucian repeated the adventure of [his]73-lucian boyhood ; for the second time [he]73-lucian scaled [the steep hillside]498-the steep hillside , and penetrated the matted brake . [He]73-lucian expected violent disillusion , but [his]73-lucian feeling was rather astonishment at the activity of boyish imagination . There was no terror nor amazement now in [the green bulwarks]2458-the green bulwarks , and the stunted undergrowth did not seem in any way extraordinary . Yet [he]73-lucian did not laugh at the memory of [his]73-lucian sensations , [he]73-lucian was not angry at the cheat . Certainly it had been all illusion , all the heats and chills of boyhood , its thoughts of terror were without significance . But [he]73-lucian recognized that the illusions of [the child]983-the child only differed from those of [the man]647-the man in that they were more picturesque ; belief in fairies and belief in [the Stock Exchange as bestowers of happiness]2461-the stock exchange as bestowers of happiness were equally vain , but the latter form of faith was ugly as well as inept . It was better , [he]73-lucian knew , and wiser , to wish for a fairy coach than to cherish longings for a well - appointed brougham and [liveried servants]2462-liveried servants . [He]73-lucian turned [his]73-lucian back on the green walls and the dark oaks without any feeling of regret or resentment . After a little while [he]73-lucian began to think of [his]73-lucian adventures with pleasure ; the ladder by which [he]73-lucian had mounted had disappeared , but [he]73-lucian was safe on the height . By the chance fancy of [a beautiful girl]2463-a beautiful girl [he]73-lucian had been redeemed from [a world of misery and torture]2464-a world of misery and torture , the world of external things into which [he]73-lucian had come [a stranger]432-a stranger , by which [he]73-lucian had been tormented . [He]73-lucian looked back at a kind of vision of [himself]73-lucian seen as [he]73-lucian was a year before , [a pitiable creature burning and twisting on the hot coals of the pit]2466-a pitiable creature burning and twisting on the hot coals of the pit , crying lamentably to [the laughing bystanders]2467-the laughing bystanders for but one drop of cold water wherewith to cool [his]73-lucian tongue . [He]73-lucian confessed to [himself]73-lucian , with some contempt , that [he]73-lucian had been [a social being]2468-a social being , depending for [his]73-lucian happiness on the goodwill of [others]2074-others ; [he]73-lucian had tried hard to write , chiefly , it was true , from love of the art , but a little from a social motive . [He]73-lucian had imagined that a written book and the praise of [responsible journals]2470-responsible journals would ensure [him]73-lucian the respect of [the county people]2471-the county people . It was a quaint idea , and [he]73-lucian saw the lamentable fallacies naked ; in the first place , [a painstaking artist in words]2472-a painstaking artist in words was not respected by [the respectable]2473-the respectable ; secondly , books should not be written with the object of gaining the goodwill of the landed and commercial interests ; thirdly and chiefly , [no man]2474-no man should in any way depend on another . From this utter darkness , from danger of madness , [the ever dear and sweet Annie]2475-the ever dear and sweet annie had rescued [him]73-lucian . Very beautifully and fitly , as [Lucian]73-lucian thought , [she]2475-the ever dear and sweet annie had done [her]2475-the ever dear and sweet annie work without any desire to benefit [him]73-lucian , [she]2475-the ever dear and sweet annie had simply willed to gratify [her]2475-the ever dear and sweet annie own passion , and in doing this had handed to [him]73-lucian the priceless secret . And [he]73-lucian , on [his]73-lucian side , had reversed the process ; merely to make [himself]73-lucian a splendid offering for the acceptance of [[his]73-lucian sweetheart]2035-his sweetheart , [he]73-lucian had cast aside the vain world , and had found the truth , which now remained with [him]73-lucian , precious and enduring . And since the news of the marriage [he]73-lucian found that [his]73-lucian worship of [her]2035-his sweetheart had by no means vanished ; rather in [his]73-lucian heart was the eternal treasure of a happy love , untarnished and spotless ; it would be like a mirror of gold without alloy , bright and lustrous for ever . For [Lucian]73-lucian , it was no defect in [the woman]2029-the woman that [she]2029-the woman was desirous and faithless ; [he]73-lucian had not conceived an affection for certain moral or intellectual accidents , but for [the very woman]2478-the very woman . Guided by the self - evident axiom that humanity is to be judged by literature , and not literature by humanity , [he]73-lucian detected the analogy between Lycidas and [Annie]75-annie . Only [the dullard]2479-the dullard would object to the nauseous ca nt of [the one]802-the one , or to the indiscretions of the other . [A sober critic]2481-a sober critic might say that [the man who could generalize [Herbert]115-herbert and [Laud]223-laud]2482-the man who could generalize herbert and laud , [Donne]224-donne and [Herrick]117-herrick , [Sanderson]225-sanderson and [Juxon]226-juxon , [Hammond]227-hammond and [Lancelot Andrewes]228-lancelot andrewes into "[1148-our corrupted clergy] [[our]1200-our corrupted Clergy]1148-our corrupted clergy " must be either [an imbecile or a scoundrel]2483-an imbecile or a scoundrel , or probably both . The judgment would be perfectly true , but as a criticism of [Lycidas]215-lycidas it would be a piece of folly . In the case of [the woman]2029-the woman one could imagine the attitude of [the conventional lover]2485-the conventional lover ; of [the chevalier who , with [his]2486-the chevalier who , with his tongue in his cheek , " reverences and respects " all women , and coming home early in the morning tongue in [his]2486-the chevalier who , with his tongue in his cheek , " reverences and respects " all women , and coming home early in the morning cheek , "[1148-our corrupted clergy] reverences and respects " [all women]2487-all women , and coming [home]308-home early in the morning]2486-the chevalier who , with his tongue in his cheek , " reverences and respects " all women , and coming home early in the morning writes a leading article on [St English Girl]2489-st english girl . [Lucian]73-lucian , on the other hand , felt profoundly grateful to the delicious [Annie]75-annie , because [she]75-annie had at precisely the right moment voluntarily removed [her]75-annie image from [his]73-lucian way . [He]73-lucian confessed to [himself]73-lucian that , latterly , [he]73-lucian had a little dreaded [her]75-annie return as an interruption ; [he]73-lucian had shivered at the thought that [their]2490-their relations would become what was so terribly called an "[1148-our corrupted clergy] intrigue " or "[1202-segars] affair . " There would be all the threadbare and common stratagems , the vulgarity of secret assignations , and an atmosphere suggesting the period of [Mr. Thomas Moore]229-mr. thomas moore and [Lord Byron]230-lord byron and "[1202-segars] [segars]1202-segars . " [Lucian]73-lucian had been afraid of all this ; [he]73-lucian had feared lest love itself should destroy love . [He]73-lucian considered that now , freed from the torment of the body , leaving untasted the green water that makes thirst more burning , [he]73-lucian was perfectly initiated in the true knowledge of the splendid and glorious love . There seemed to [him]73-lucian a monstrous paradox in the assertion that there could be no true love without a corporal presence of [the beloved]2491-the beloved ; even the popular sayings of "[1202-segars] Absence makes the heart grow fonder , " and "[231-cousin edward] familiarity breeds contempt , " witnessed to the contrary . [He]73-lucian thought , sighing , and with compassion , of the manner in which [men]1715-men are continually led astray by the cheat of the senses . In order that [the unborn]2493-the unborn might still be added to the born , nature had inspired [men]1715-men with the wild delusion that the bodily companionship of [the lover]2495-the lover and [the beloved]2491-the beloved was desirable above all things , and so , by the false show of pleasure , [the human race]2497-the human race was chained to vanity , and doomed to an eternal thirst for the non - existent . Again and again [he]73-lucian gave thanks for [his]73-lucian own escape ; [he]73-lucian had been set free from a life of vice and sin and folly , from all the dangers and illusions that are most dreaded by [the wise]2498-the wise . [He]73-lucian laughed as [he]73-lucian remembered what would be the common view of the situation . [An ordinary lover]2499-an ordinary lover would suffer all the sting of sorrow and contempt ; there would be grief for [a lost mistress]2500-a lost mistress , and rage at [her]2500-a lost mistress faithlessness , and hate in the heart ; one foolish passion driving on another , and driving [the man]647-the man to ruin . For what would be commonly called [the real woman]2502-the real woman [he]73-lucian now cared nothing ; if [he]73-lucian had heard that [she]2502-the real woman had died in [[her]2502-the real woman farm in [Utter Gwent]36-utter gwent]2503-her farm in utter gwent , [he]73-lucian would have experienced only a passing sorrow , such as [he]73-lucian might feel at the death of [any one [he]73-lucian had once known]2504-any one he had once known . But [he]73-lucian did not think of [[the young farmer]2505-the young farmer 's wife]2506-the young farmer 's wife as [the real Annie]2507-the real annie ; [he]73-lucian did not think of the frost - bitten leaves in winter as the real rose . Indeed , the life of [many]2508-many reminded [him]73-lucian of the flowers ; perhaps more especially of those flowers which to all appearance are for many years but dull and dusty clumps of green , and suddenly , in one night , burst into the flame of blossom , and fill all the misty lawns with odor ; till the morning . It was in that night that the flower lived , not through the long unprofitable years ; and , in like manner , many human lives , [he]73-lucian thought , were born in the evening and dead before the coming of day . But [he]73-lucian had preserved the precious flower in all its glory , not suffering it to wither in the hard light , but keeping it in a secret place , where it could never be destroyed . Truly now , and for the first time , [he]73-lucian possessed [Annie]75-annie , as [a man]687-a man possesses the gold which [he]73-lucian has dug from [the rock]2510-the rock and purged of its baseness . [He]73-lucian was musing over these things when a piece of news , very strange and unexpected , arrived at [the rectory]272-the rectory . [A distant , almost a mythical relative , known from childhood]2512-a distant , almost a mythical relative , known from childhood as "[231-cousin edward] [Cousin Edward]231-cousin edward in [the Isle of Wight]37-the isle of wight , " had died , and by [some strange freak]2513-some strange freak had left [Lucian]73-lucian two thousand pounds . It was a pleasure to give [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father five hundred pounds , and [the rector]2515-the rector on [his]73-lucian side forgot for a couple of days to lean [his]2515-the rector head on [his]2515-the rector hand . From [the rest of [the capital]2517-the capital]2516-the rest of the capital , which was well invested , [Lucian]73-lucian found [he]73-lucian would derive something between sixty and seventy pounds a year , and [his]73-lucian old desires for literature and a refuge in [the murmuring streets]2518-the murmuring streets returned to [him]73-lucian . [He]73-lucian longed to be free from the incantations that surrounded [him]73-lucian in [the country]459-the country , to work and live in a new atmosphere ; and so , with many good wishes from [[his]73-lucian father]341-his father , [he]73-lucian came to [the retreat in [the waste places of [London]11-london]2522-the waste places of london]2521-the retreat in the waste places of london . [He]73-lucian was in high spirits when [he]73-lucian found [the square , clean room]2523-the square , clean room , horribly furnished , in [the by - street that branched from [the main road]273-the main road]2524-the by - street that branched from the main road , and advanced in an unlovely sweep to [the mud pits]2526-the mud pits and the desolation that was neither [town nor country]2527-town nor country . On every side [monotonous grey streets]2528-monotonous grey streets , [each house]2529-each house the replica of [[its]2529-each house neighbor]2530-its neighbor , to the east [an unexplored wilderness]2531-an unexplored wilderness , north and west and south [the brickfields]2532-the brickfields and [market - gardens]2533-market - gardens , everywhere [the ruins of [the country]459-the country]2534-the ruins of the country , the tracks where [sweet lanes]2536-sweet lanes had been , gangrened stumps of trees , the relics of hedges , here and there an oak stripped of its bark , white and haggard and leprous , like a corpse . And the air seemed always grey , and the smoke from [the brickfields]2532-the brickfields was grey . At first [he]73-lucian scarcely realized the quarter into which chance had led [him]73-lucian . [His]73-lucian only thought was of the great adventure of letters in which [he]73-lucian proposed to engage , and [his]73-lucian first glance round [his]73-lucian "[231-cousin edward] bed - sitting - room " showed [him]73-lucian that there was no piece of furniture suitable for [his]73-lucian purpose . The table , like the rest of [the suite]874-the suite , was of bird's - eye maple ; but [the maker]2539-the maker seemed to have penetrated the druidic secret of the rocking - stone , the thing was in a state of unstable equilibrium perpetually . For some days [he]73-lucian wandered through [the streets]1118-the streets , inspecting [the second - hand furniture shops]2541-the second - hand furniture shops , and at last , in a forlorn byway , found an old Japanese bureau , dishonored and forlorn , standing amongst rusty bedsteads , sorry china , and all the refuse of [homes]2542-homes dead and desolate . The bureau pleased [him]73-lucian in spite of its grime and grease and dirt . Inlaid mother - of - pearl , the gleam of lacquer dragons in red gold , and hints of curious design shone through the film of neglect and ill - usage , and when [the woman of [the shop]2544-the shop]2543-the woman of the shop showed [him]73-lucian the drawers and well and pigeon - holes , [he]73-lucian saw that it would be an apt instrument for [his]73-lucian studies . The bureau was carried to [[his]73-lucian room]632-his room and replaced the "[231-cousin edward] bird's - eye " table under the gas - jet . As [Lucian]73-lucian arranged what papers [he]73-lucian had accumulated : the sketches of hopeless experiments , shreds and tatters of stories begun but never completed , outlines of plots , two or three notebooks scribbled through and through with impressions of [the abandoned hills]2546-the abandoned hills , [he]73-lucian felt a thrill of exaltation at the prospect of work to be accomplished , of [a new world all open before [him]73-lucian]2547-a new world all open before him . [He]73-lucian set out on the adventure with a fury of enthusiasm ; [his]73-lucian last thought at night when all [the maze of streets]2548-the maze of streets was empty and silent was of the problem , and [his]73-lucian dreams ran on phrases , and when [he]73-lucian awoke in the morning [he]73-lucian was eager to get back to [his]73-lucian desk . [He]73-lucian immersed [himself]73-lucian in a minute , almost a microscopic analysis of fine literature . It was no longer enough , as in the old days , to feel the charm and incantation of a line or a word ; [he]73-lucian wished to penetrate the secret , to understand something of the wonderful suggestion , all apart from the sense , that seemed to [him]73-lucian the differentia of literature , as distinguished from the long follies of "[231-cousin edward] character - drawing , " "[231-cousin edward] psychological analysis , " and all the stuff that went to make the three - volume novel of commerce . [He]73-lucian found [himself]73-lucian curiously strengthened by the change from [the hills]1660-the hills to [the streets]1118-the streets . There could be no doubt , [he]73-lucian thought , that living a lonely life , interested only in [himself]73-lucian and [his]73-lucian own thoughts , [he]73-lucian had become in a measure inhuman . The form of external things , black depths in [woods]2551-woods , [pools in lonely places]2552-pools in lonely places , [those still valleys curtained by hills on every side]2553-those still valleys curtained by hills on every side , sounding always with the ripple of [their]1660-the hills brooks , had become to [him]73-lucian an influence like that of a drug , giving a certain peculiar color and outline to [his]73-lucian thoughts . And from early boyhood there had been another strange flavor in [his]73-lucian life , the dream of the old Roman world , those curious impressions that [he]73-lucian had gathered from [the white walls of [Caermaen]7-caermaen]2554-the white walls of caermaen , and from [the looming bastions of [the fort]1672-the fort]2555-the looming bastions of the fort . It was in reality the subconscious fancies of many years that had rebuilt [the golden city]2557-the golden city , and had shown [him]73-lucian the vine - trellis and the marbles and the sunlight in [the garden of [Avallaunius]31-avallaunius]1124-the garden of avallaunius . And the rapture of love had made it all so vivid and warm with life , that even now , when [he]73-lucian let [his]73-lucian pen drop , the rich noise of [the tavern]2342-the tavern and the chant of [the theatre]1173-the theatre sounded above the murmur of [the streets]1118-the streets . Looking back , it was as much a part of [his]73-lucian life as [his]73-lucian schooldays , and the tessellated pavements were as real as the square of faded carpet beneath [his]73-lucian feet . But [he]73-lucian felt that [he]73-lucian had escaped . [He]73-lucian could now survey those splendid and lovely visions from without , as if [he]73-lucian read of opium dreams , and [he]73-lucian no longer dreaded a weird suggestion that had once beset [him]73-lucian , that [his]73-lucian very soul was being molded into [the hills]1660-the hills , and passing into the black mirror of [still waterpools]2563-still waterpools . [He]73-lucian had taken refuge in [the streets]1118-the streets , in [the harbor of [a modern suburb]2566-a modern suburb]2565-the harbor of a modern suburb , from the vague , dreaded magic that had charmed [his]73-lucian life . Whenever [he]73-lucian felt inclined to listen to the old wood - whisper or to the singing of the fauns [he]73-lucian bent more earnestly to [his]73-lucian work , turning a deaf ear to the incantations . In the curious labor of the bureau [he]73-lucian found refreshment that was continually renewed . [He]73-lucian experienced again , and with a far more violent impulse , the enthusiasm that had attended the writing of [his]73-lucian book a year or two before , and so , perhaps , passed from one drug to another . It was , indeed , with something of rapture that [he]73-lucian imagined the great procession of years all to be devoted to the intimate analysis of words , to the construction of the sentence , as if it were a piece of jewelry or mosaic . Sometimes , in the pauses of the work , [he]73-lucian would pace up and down [[his]73-lucian cell]2567-his cell , looking out of the window now and again and gazing for an instant into [the melancholy street]2568-the melancholy street . As the year advanced the days grew more and more misty , and [he]73-lucian found [himself]73-lucian the inhabitant of [a little island wreathed about with the waves of a white and solemn sea]2569-a little island wreathed about with the waves of a white and solemn sea . In the afternoon the fog would grow denser , shutting out not only sight but sound ; the shriek of [the garden]1648-the garden gates , the jangling of the tram - bell echoed as if from a far way . Then there were days of heavy incessant rain ; [he]73-lucian could see a grey drifting sky and the drops plashing in [the street]1858-the street , and [the houses]2572-the houses all dripping and saddened with wet . [He]73-lucian cured [himself]73-lucian of one great aversion . [He]73-lucian was no longer nauseated at the sight of a story begun and left unfinished . Formerly , even when an idea rose in [his]73-lucian mind bright and wonderful , [he]73-lucian had always approached the paper with a feeling of sickness and dislike , remembering all the hopeless beginnings [he]73-lucian had made . But now [he]73-lucian understood that to begin a romance was almost a separate and special art , a thing apart from the story , to be practiced with sedulous care . Whenever an opening scene occurred to [him]73-lucian [he]73-lucian noted it roughly in a book , and [he]73-lucian devoted many long winter evenings to the elaboration of these beginnings . Sometimes the first impression would yield only a paragraph or a sentence , and once or twice but a splendid and sonorous word , which seemed to Lucian all dim and rich with unsurmised adventure . But often [he]73-lucian was able to write three or four vivid pages , studying above all things the hint and significance of the words and actions , striving to work into the lines the atmosphere of expectation and promise , and the murmur of wonderful events to come . In this one department of [his]73-lucian task the labor seemed almost endless . [He]73-lucian would finish a few pages and then rewrite them , using the same incident and nearly the same words , but altering that indefinite something which is scarcely so much style as manner , or atmosphere . [He]73-lucian was astonished at the enormous change that was thus effected , and often , though [he]73-lucian [himself]73-lucian had done the work , [he]73-lucian could scarcely describe in words how it was done . But it was clear that in this art of manner , or suggestion , lay all the chief secrets of literature , that by it all the great miracles were performed . Clearly it was not style , for style in itself was untranslatable , but it was that high theurgic magic that made the English Don Quixote , roughly traduced by [some Jervas]232-some jervas , perhaps the best of all English books . And it was the same element that made the journey of [Roderick Random]233-roderick random to [London]11-london , so ostensibly a narrative of coarse jokes and common experiences and burlesque manners , told in no very choice diction , essentially a wonderful vision of the eighteenth century , carrying to one 's very nostrils the aroma of [the Great North Road]2573-the great north road , iron - bound under black frost , darkened beneath [shuddering woods]2574-shuddering woods , haunted by [highwaymen]2575-highwaymen , with an adventure waiting beyond every turn , and [great old echoing inns in [the midst of lonely winter lands]2577-the midst of lonely winter lands]2576-great old echoing inns in the midst of lonely winter lands . It was this magic that [Lucian]73-lucian sought for [his]73-lucian opening chapters ; [he]73-lucian tried to find that quality that gives to words something beyond their sound and beyond their meaning , that in the first lines of a book should whisper things unintelligible but all significant . Often [he]73-lucian worked for many hours without success , and the grim wet dawn once found [him]73-lucian still searching for hieroglyphic sentences , for words mystical , symbolic . On the shelves , in the upper part of [[his]73-lucian bureau]2578-his bureau , [he]73-lucian had placed the books which , however various as to matter , seemed to have a part in this curious quality of suggestion , and in that sphere which might almost be called supernatural . To these books [he]73-lucian often had recourse , when further effort appeared altogether hopeless , and certain pages in [Coleridge]234-coleridge and [Edgar Allan Poe]235-edgar allan poe had the power of holding [him]73-lucian in a trance of delight , subject to emotions and impressions which [he]73-lucian knew to transcend altogether the realm of the formal understanding . Such lines as : [Bottomless vales]2579-bottomless vales and boundless floods , And chasms , and caves , and [Titan woods]2580-titan woods , With forms that [no man]2474-no man can discover For the dews that drip all over ; had for [Lucian]73-lucian more than the potency of a drug , lulling [him]73-lucian into a splendid waking - sleep , every word being a supreme incantation . And it was not only [his]73-lucian mind that was charmed by such passages , for [he]73-lucian felt at the same time a strange and delicious bodily languor that held [him]73-lucian motionless , without the desire or power to stir from [his]73-lucian seat . And there were certain phrases in [Kubla Khan]38-kubla khan that had such a magic that [he]73-lucian would sometimes wake up , as it were , to the consciousness that [he]73-lucian had been lying on the bed or sitting in the chair by [the bureau]2582-the bureau , repeating a single line over and over again for two or three hours . Yet [he]73-lucian knew perfectly well that [he]73-lucian had not been really asleep ; a little effort recalled a constant impression of the wall - paper , with its pink flowers on a buff ground , and of the muslin - curtained window , letting in the grey winter light . [He]73-lucian had been some seven months in [London]11-london when this odd experience first occurred to [him]73-lucian . The day opened dreary and cold and clear , with a gusty and restless wind whirling round the corner of [the street]1858-the street , and lifting the dead leaves and scraps of paper that littered [the roadway]2584-the roadway into eddying mounting circles , as if a storm of black rain were to come . [Lucian]73-lucian had sat late the night before , and rose in the morning feeling weary and listless and heavy - headed . While [he]73-lucian dressed , [his]73-lucian legs dragged [him]73-lucian as with weights , and [he]73-lucian staggered and nearly fell in bending down to the mat outside for [his]73-lucian tea - tray . [He]73-lucian lit the spirit lamp on the hearth with shaking , unsteady hands , and could scarcely pour out the tea when it was ready . A delicate cup of tea was one of [his]73-lucian few luxuries ; [he]73-lucian was fond of the strange flavor of the green leaf , and this morning [he]73-lucian drank the straw - colored liquid eagerly , hoping it would disperse the cloud of languor . [He]73-lucian tried [his]73-lucian best to coerce [himself]73-lucian into the sense of vigor and enjoyment with which [he]73-lucian usually began the day , walking briskly up and down and arranging [his]73-lucian papers in order . But [he]73-lucian could not free [himself]73-lucian from depression ; even as [he]73-lucian opened the dear bureau a wave of melancholy came upon [him]73-lucian , and [he]73-lucian began to ask [himself]73-lucian whether [he]73-lucian were not pursuing a vain dream , searching for treasures that had no existence . [He]73-lucian drew out [[his]73-lucian cousin]1735-his cousin 's letter and read it again , sadly enough . After all there was a good deal of truth in what [she]1735-his cousin said ; [he]73-lucian had "[231-cousin edward] overrated " [his]73-lucian powers , [he]73-lucian had [no friends]2586-no friends , no real education . [He]73-lucian began to count up the months since [he]73-lucian had come to [London]11-london ; [he]73-lucian had received [his]73-lucian two thousand pounds in March , and in May [he]73-lucian had said good - bye to [the woods]331-the woods and to [the dear and friendly paths]2588-the dear and friendly paths . May , June , July , August , September , October , November , and half of December had gone by ; and what had [he]73-lucian to show ? Nothing but the experiment , the attempt , futile scribblings which had no end nor shining purpose . There was nothing in [his]1204-he desk that [he]1204-he could produce as evidence of [his]1204-he capacity , no fragment even of accomplishment . It was a thought of intense bitterness , but it seemed as if [the barbarians]642-the barbarians were in the rightâ€”a[687-a man] place in [a house of business]1188-a house of business would have been more suitable . [He]1204-he leaned [his]1204-he head on [his]1204-he desk overwhelmed with the severity of [his]1204-he own judgment . [He]1204-he tried to comfort [himself]1204-he again by the thought of all the hours of happy enthusiasm [he]1204-he had spent amongst [his]1204-he papers , working for a great idea with infinite patience . [He]1204-he recalled to mind something that [he]1204-he had always tried to keep in the background of [his]1204-he hopes , the foundation - stone of [his]1204-he life , which [he]1204-he had hidden out of sight . Deep in [his]1204-he heart was the hope that [he]1204-he might one day write a valiant book ; [he]1204-he scarcely dared to entertain the aspiration , [he]1204-he felt [his]1204-he incapacity too deeply , but yet this longing was the foundation of all [his]1204-he painful and patient effort . This [he]1204-he had proposed in secret to [himself]1204-he , that if [he]1204-he labored without ceasing , without tiring , [he]1204-he might produce something which would at all events be art , which would stand wholly apart from the objects shaped like books , printed with [printers]1205-printers ' ink , and called by the name of books that [he]1204-he had read . [Giotto]236-giotto , [he]1204-he knew , was [a painter]2344-a painter , and [the man who imitated walnut - wood on the deal doors opposite]1207-the man who imitated walnut - wood on the deal doors opposite was [a painter]2344-a painter , and [he]1204-he had wished to be [a very humble pupil in the class of the former]1209-a very humble pupil in the class of the former . It was better , [he]1204-he thought , to fail in attempting exquisite things than to succeed in the department of the utterly contemptible ; [he]1204-he had vowed [he]1204-he would be [the dunce of [[Cervantes]237-cervantes 's school]1211-cervantes 's school rather than top - boy in [the academy of A Bad Un to Beat and [Millicent]127-millicent 's Marriage]1212-the academy of a bad un to beat and millicent 's marriage]1210-the dunce of cervantes 's school rather than top - boy in the academy of a bad un to beat and millicent 's marriage . And with this purpose [he]1204-he had devoted [himself]1204-he to laborious and joyous years , so that however mean [his]1204-he capacity , the pains should not be wanting . [He]1204-he tried now to rouse [himself]1204-he from a growing misery by the recollection of this high aim , but it all seemed hopeless vanity . [He]1204-he looked out into [the grey street]1213-the grey street , and it stood a symbol of [his]1204-he life , chill and dreary and grey and vexed with a horrible wind . There were [the dull inhabitants of [the quarter]2445-the quarter]1214-the dull inhabitants of the quarter going about [their]1214-the dull inhabitants of the quarter common business ; [a man]687-a man was crying " mackerel "[687-a man] in a doleful voice , slowly passing up [the street]1858-the street , and staring into [the white - curtained " parlors]2590-the white - curtained " parlors , "[73-lucian] searching for the face of [a purchaser]1218-a purchaser behind the India - rubber plants , stuffed birds , and piles of gaudy gilt books that adorned the windows . One of the blistered doors over the way banged , and [a woman]1770-a woman came scurrying out on some errand , and the garden gate shrieked two melancholy notes as [she]1770-a woman opened it and let it swing back after [her]1770-a woman . [The little patches called [gardens]1221-gardens]1220-the little patches called gardens were mostly untilled , uncared for , squares of slimy moss , dotted with clumps of coarse ugly grass , but here and there were the blackened and rotting remains of sunflowers and marigolds . And beyond , [he]1204-he knew , stretched the labyrinth of [streets more or less squalid]1222-streets more or less squalid , but all grey and dull , and behind were the mud pits and the steaming heaps of yellowish bricks , and to the north was a great wide cold waste , treeless , desolate , swept by bitter wind . It was all like [his]1204-he own life , [he]1204-he said again to [himself]1204-he , a maze of unprofitable dreariness and desolation , and [his]1204-he mind grew as black and hopeless as the winter sky . The morning went thus dismally till twelve o'clock , and [he]1204-he put on [his]1204-he hat and great - coat . [He]1204-he always went out for an hour every day between twelve and one ; the exercise was a necessity , and [the landlady]1223-the landlady made [his]1204-he bed in the interval . The wind blew the smoke from the chimneys into [his]1204-he face as [he]1204-he shut the door , and with the acrid smoke came the prevailing odor of [the street]1858-the street , a blend of cabbage - water and burnt bones and the faint sickly vapor from [the brickfields]2532-the brickfields . [Lucian]73-lucian walked mechanically for the hour , going eastward , along [the main road]273-the main road . The wind pierced [him]73-lucian , and the dust was blinding , and the dreariness of [the street]1858-the street increased [his]73-lucian misery . The row of [common shops]1228-common shops , full of common things , [the blatant public - houses]1229-the blatant public - houses , [the Independent chapel]1230-the independent chapel , a horrible stucco parody of [a Greek temple]1231-a greek temple with a façade of hideous columns that was a nightmare , villas like [smug Pharisees]1232-smug pharisees , [shops]1233-shops again , [a church in [cheap Gothic]1235-cheap gothic , [an old garden]1236-an old garden blasted and riven by [the builder]1237-the builder]1234-a church in cheap gothic , an old garden blasted and riven by the builder , these were the pictures of the way . When [he]73-lucian got [home]308-home again [he]73-lucian flung [himself]73-lucian on the bed , and lay there stupidly till sheer hunger roused [him]73-lucian . [He]73-lucian ate a hunch of bread and drank some water , and began to pace up and down [the room]2083-the room , wondering whether there were no escape from despair . Writing seemed quite impossible , and hardly knowing what [he]73-lucian did [he]73-lucian opened [his]73-lucian bureau and took out a book from the shelves . As [his]73-lucian eyes fell on the page the air grew dark and heavy as night , and the wind wailed suddenly , loudly , terribly . " By [woman]2591-woman wailing for [[her]2591-woman Demon lover]2592-her demon lover . "[73-lucian] The words were on [his]73-lucian lips when [he]73-lucian raised [his]73-lucian eyes again . A broad band of pale clear light was shining into [the room]2083-the room , and when [he]73-lucian looked out of the window [he]73-lucian saw [the road]287-the road all brightened by glittering pools of water , and as the last drops of the rain - storm starred these mirrors the sun sank into the wrack . [Lucian]73-lucian gazed about [him]73-lucian , perplexed , till [his]73-lucian eyes fell on the clock above [his]73-lucian empty hearth . [He]73-lucian had been sitting , motionless , for nearly two hours without any sense of the passage of time , and without ceasing [he]73-lucian had murmured those words as [he]73-lucian dreamed an endless wonderful story . [He]73-lucian experienced somewhat the sensations of [Coleridge]234-coleridge [himself]73-lucian ; strange , amazing , ineffable things seemed to have been presented to [him]73-lucian , not in the form of the idea , but actually and materially , but [he]73-lucian was less fortunate than [Coleridge]234-coleridge in that [he]73-lucian could not , even vaguely , image to [himself]73-lucian what [he]73-lucian had seen . Yet when [he]73-lucian searched [his]73-lucian mind [he]73-lucian knew that the consciousness of [the room in which [he]73-lucian sat]1242-the room in which he sat had never left [him]73-lucian ; [he]73-lucian had seen the thick darkness gather , and had heard the whirl of rain hissing through the air .
